speakeroldname: Mr. David Barrett (Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca) moved:
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
That this House urge the government to abrogate the
Canada-U.S. Free Hade Agreement.
He said: Mr. Speaker, in the short time I have in front of me it will be impossible to give a detailed catalogue of the devastation of the free trade agreement and the impact it has had negatively on all Canadians.
Before I go into those specifics, I think it is worth while to remember that we did have an open debate in this country during the 1988 election campaign regarding the free trade agreement.
At that time, and prior to the campaign itself in the national debate, there were many people who were involved who were not running for office, but from the business community, from the trade union movement and interested sectors of academics and others who expressed opinions. There were a number of people who spent a significant amount of their time extolling the virtues of this agreement.
I remember clearly being in a debate with Dr. John Crispo and at that time doing a radio interview with Dr. Crispo. I remember him as one of the spokespersons advocating the free trade agreement, repeating the government's promises-although he was not speaking for the government-about the thousands of jobs that were going to be created, about the great expansion that would take place in the Canadian economy and virtual guarantees almost that the government was going to take care of retraining for those people who admittedly would be displaced, albeit small numbers the government said.
It is in that atmosphere and that context that I want to focus on the reasons why I think the agreement should be abrogated. Anything less would be a cop-out in my opinion. Renegotiation would be a cop-out. As a matter of fact, if I may digress just for a moment, the free trade agreement is being forced open into a form of renegotiation in any event through what is happening with NAFTA.
Those people who supported the free trade agreement were wrong. It was a serious mistake in my opinion because there were not tens of thousands of jobs created because of the free trade agreement. There was not the massive infusion of new capital into this country so that we could play on a level playing field. Of course during the course of my remarks I will quote statistics from Statistics Canada, paid for by taxpayers, to substantiate these claims.
It has been a disaster. It has ripped the guts and the heart out of the manufacturing base of this country. It has destroyed the economy of the provinces of Ontario and Quebec more than any other regions in this country, and has continued to be ignored by the United States. In any instance it feels Canada may have been out-competing the Americans, it immediately uses tactics to attack Canadian interests in spite of the agreement that it claims would give us a level playing field.
What has the damage been in three years of the free trade agreement? Since the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement came into effect, the destruction of manufacturing jobs has been dramatic and devastating. To find a period of greater collapse of manufacturing employment, one has to go back to the Great Depression in this country. Manufacturing employment fell by 29.7 per cent in the Great Depression. The current recession has seen manufacturing employment fall by 23.1 per cent and there is no sign of it stopping.
I repeat, during the height of the Depression, Canada's manufacturing employment fell by 29.7 per cent. Since we signed the treaty on January 1, 1988, we have lost 23.1 per cent of our manufacturing employment, part of it due to the recession, most of it due to the free trade agreement. I will come to those numbers in a moment.
A number of subsectors have already surpassed the Depression figures. Those levels have gone higher than the Depression and they are in the area of food, beverages, leather, textiles, clothing, printing, publishing and chemicals.
We have lost more jobs in the food, beverages, leather, textiles, clothing, printing, publishing and chemicals manufacturing sector than we did during the Depression. Furthermore, between June 1989 and October 1991, there was a net loss of 461,000 manufacturing jobs, which means 23.1 per cent.

My good friends claim that most of these were lost to the Depression. Using the government's own Department of Statistics, 150,000 of these jobs disappeared before the formal onset of the recession. The recession and its definition of an onset is laid out clearly by the number of months of a downturn in the economy. One hundred and fifty thousand jobs lost before the recession was declared to be happening.
There was a drop of 270,000 jobs in 1981-82 in that recession when the Liberals were in power. I point that out because this government is fond of attacking the Liberals for their mismanagement of the economy. In actual fact, as hard as the Liberals tried, they could not screw it up as much as the Tories did. Only 22 per cent of those jobs lost during the Liberal recession were due to permanent plant closures. But in the first three years of the free trade agreement, 65 per cent of the jobs lost in this country were due to permanent plant closures.
Permanent plant closures, 65 per cent of those jobs lost because of that. This government signed an agreement that led to this catastrophe in the economy and it has the nerve to spend a million dollars to hire a Harvard professor to tell it what is wrong with productivity. On page 69 of the report from that Harvard professor, he points out that one of the problems is the free trade agreement.
Isn't that ironic, Mr. Speaker? And now it is spending $15 million to go around telling Canadians to be more productive. All you need is a job to be productive, and that is pretty hard for most Canadians, especially those who are unemployed.
In comparison with the United States, if we want to put this in the same frame of the recession then let us put it in the framework of the impact on the United States during this same period of time. While Canada experienced a 23.1 per cent decline in manufacturing jobs, the United States realized only a 6.3 per cent loss in its manufacturing jobs; almost four to one; three and a half to one. If the recession is to blame then there should be a comparative percentage of at least relative closeness to the damage that has been done by the recession itself. In this instance, we can see clearly that the United States has not suffered nearly as much as Canada.
Supply
Three and a half to one ratio on a percentage basis of job loss compared to the United States. Is our recession three and a half times worse? If you want to use that frame, the government will deny it. The fact is the devastation of the free trade agreement has caused that dramatic change in the percentage of jobs lost.
From 1985 to 1988 Canada averaged a $4.7 billion surplus with the United States in its current account balance. That is goods, services, interest and dividends. From 1985 to 1988 the Tories reputation of maintaining a surplus balance of payments with the United States was outstanding. What happened when they signed the free trade agreement? Let us look at these figures.
That surplus turned to a $2.4 billion deficit in 1989, a $0.4 billion deficit in 1990, and reached a $3.1 billion deficit in 1991, according to the government's own figures. The government's own statistics and the government's own figures show the dramatic turnaround not only in the job loss but also in the balance of trade account between Canada and the United States.
The other canard is offshore investment. Again I use the government's own statistics and point out what has happened since this government signed the free trade agreement. In 1990-91, 97 per cent of foreign direct investment in Canada was takeovers of Canadian-based companies. Only 3 per cent was new investment. This exceeds the five-year average proportion of takeovers, which is 90 per cent.
Every single figure I have given, every single statistic I have quoted has been from the government's own booklets, Department of Statistics, or any other document it has produced. No matter how you slice it the free trade agreement has been a disaster to the people of Canada, it has been a disaster to the small Canadian manufacturing sector, and it has been a disaster for our future.
How do we get out of this mess? The first thing we must do is have the courage to say this is Canada, we must stand up on our own feet in the world and say we have been burned by this government's disastrous agreement, but our only option is to give six months notice to abrogate the treaty and then pick up the pieces from there.

There are those who say now we will really be in trouble. It is very interesting. First of all they gave us this illness and then they say, oh no, radical surgery will only kill us. Radical surgery gives us a chance to cut out this disaster. If we continue with the illness, we will all be dead waiting for heaven to arrive.
There is a middle ground too that I must address because I am a politician and I am speaking about politics. It was a political decision by this government to go ahead with the free trade agreement. As I mentioned earlier, there was a great debate in this country led by the former prime minister of this country and the former leader of this party, Ed Broadbent, and of course John Tbrner.
John TUmer as a Liberal leader and the Leader of the Official Opposition took a dramatic position that was in direct opposition to the position his party had had for years. John Tbrner as a great Canadian and also a very good friend of mine had the courage to stand up and say to all Canadians he as the leader of the Liberal Party would if elected not sign the free trade agreement. He made profound statements along with my own leader, Ed Broadbent, about the dangers of signing this agreement and pledged his party not to sign the deal.
The political atmosphere has changed. I have listed statistically the devastation of this agreement. Our party has taken the position of abrogating, the government wants to defend itself on its own mortal blows that it has given itself, but I want to talk about the disappointment of the Official Opposition.
Once John Tbrner left, the Official Opposition took the position away from John Turner and went back on the fence and said it wanted to renegotiate. Renegotiate is a cop-out. Renegotiate and cop-out are synonymous. There is no way to escape it. It is far more dangerous for the Canadian people to hear and believe that somehow there is some way of renegotiating this treaty to protect what we already have and regain what we have lost.
That is fatuous nonsense. It borders on being sanctimonious political cant. There is no possible way you can renegotiate this deal. What the Liberal Party does not understand and does not seem to appreciate is that it is not one Single arena they would have to negotiate in, but three arenas; with the White House, with the Senate,
and with Congress and each one of them would take its pound of flesh.
If anybody has any belief that the United States was committed to staying on a level playing field, let us take a look at the damage it has done sector by sector in attacking the Canadian economy.
In almost every single arena, the United States has assaulted those Canadian industries which showed they were able to compete. The United States has retaliated in softwood lumber, in beef, in pork, in whole ranges of areas and has gone further than specific battles, but it has also taken on sectors in our economy that we thought were protected, like automobiles and automobile parts.
Let us look at the automobile parts decision and the decision by this government to fight back against the Honda ruling. The Honda ruling was made not to punish Honda but to send a clear signal out to any other off-shore investor who was looking to Canada as a potential investment area, saying: "Hey, we have Canada under control because of the free trade agreement. If you invest in Canada, we will harass you".
The Honda decision was made by the United States to harass off-shore investors by giving them a signal that if they invest in Canada any attempt to enter into the. U.S. market will be subject to U.S. interpretation of content rule.
Last week I raised the question in this House about the unfair competition by Americans offering tax benefits. I raised the example of just one small company, the Central Power and Light Company in Corpus Christi, Texas which was offering companies 10 years of tax relief if they would come down. Other financial benefits were offered to come to Corpus Christi.
All of the ads and all of the promises offered by that light company are a violation of the free trade agreement, every single one of them. What has the minister's response been in this House to these violations? He said: "The member has a point here and we brought it up with GATT".
GATT is not concerned with this. If this government had any courage at all, it would use the FTA panels that it says are so successful in defending Canadian interests. This is a violation of the FTA. This is a violation of the free trade agreement that this government signed and it
May 11, 1992

does not have the courage to face the Americans with these violations that are taking place every single day.
The list of events and the wrongs under this agreement goes on and on and on. The next federal election in this country will be fought over this issue along with the North American Free Trade Agreement. Tens of thousands of people in this country have already lost hope. Any polling interpretation or any reading of the mood of the Canadian people is one of giving up.
During the 1988 election I said that this would be an election about the loss of the innocence of Canada. My oldest son asked why I made that remark and I said: "This will be the first time in the history of this nation that we will be, if the Tories are elected, electing a government that has given up on Canada".
From shore to shore, we have had a government that has not understood clearly what this nation is all about. There are only 27 million people in this country. We have a cornucopia of resources. None of those resources were put in the ground by the multinational corporations. None were put in the ground by the oil companies.
The oil well, the natural gas well, the timber, the fisheries, the minerals in the ground of this great nation belong to the people of this nation to be leased or used by those manufacturers. Those God-given resources were to be husbanded by prudent, thoughtful, cautious governments. They were not to be given away.
The first give-away pattern took place when the great railroads were built across this country. But no one ever envisioned that we would some day reach the point where the government gave up on Canada and all the resources of Canada.
What is to be done? There are many options. The first thing that has to be done is to abrogate the treaty, take an inventory of where we are in this country and then from there, begin to develop our own resources. We are not a poverty-stricken nation but we will soon be driven to that category under this government's policies.
We should reassess our economic foundation, develop an industrial strategy that is moulded on a more competitive view of the world than just surrending to the United

States and international corporations' domination of a three-country market through NAFTA, and take a look at where we are financially and internationally in the world. There are options for us.
I presented to the Minister of Finance an option in terms of jobs right now through a municipal infrastructure using municipal bonds sponsored by this federal government and allowing RRSP funds to be invested there, at no cost to the government. It is an imaginative, thoughtful but different approach. It should examine the proposal instead of brushing it aside.
Let us look at the option of alternate financing as the provinces of Alberta and Ontario can do through treasury branches. Let us have the option of a fiscal instrument owned by the people of this country as Margaret Thatcher did, using the post office in great Britain as a fiscal instrument for mobilizing indigenous funds for industrial development in Britain.
It is ironic that I should speak of Margaret Thatcher. I find it interesting, but she never once destroyed the instrument that was started by the Labour Party, using the post office as a fiscal instrument for mobilizing funds for indigenous development in that country.
On and on and on. We have abandoned our control of oil. We must continue to supply, because of this agreement, the U.S. and the U.S. market at the same level. We have not had the guts to determine that oil should be refined and processed in this country, while we subsidize gasoline in the U.S. economy to compete with Canadian workers.
Timing to natural gas, tens of billions of cubic feet of natural gas have been sold out under this administration simply for a fast buck at low prices. These are stupid, stupid decisions made by a government that has lost its courage, its nerve, and its vision of what this country should be.
I am deeply disappointed, as I conclude my remarks, not so much in this government that has proven it is a failure, but much more in the Official Opposition which has abandoned the position of the right hon. member for Vancouver Quadra of abrogating the free trade agreement. speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I guess the answer to the hon. member's question about what the NDP leader was talking about will never be known because we sure did not get an answer from the hon. member.
I am vety pleased to have an opportunity to speak on this motion. I will read it again so that people can hear it:
That this House urges the government to abrogate the
Canada -U.S. Free Trade Agreement.
It is a seductive motion. It is preying on the concerns that Canadians have about the economy. I listened to the hon. member very carefully. There is an old expression: Figures lie and liars figure. The speech twisted figures, it distorted facts, it even misquotes people. Michael Porter was misquoted. Michael Porter is very supportive of the free trade agreement, contrary to what my hon. friend has said.
The motion is the wrong way to go. It shows the fundamental difference between the New Democratic Party and the Liberal Party on the one hand and the Progressive Conservative government on the other hand. Canada will not strengthen its economy by protectionism. Members of the NDP are offering Canadians a Charlie Brown security blanket. They are saying, forget about the free trade agreement.
The NDP policy is "The future is the past". Let us go back to the old comfortable days, the 1960s and 1970s when things were just great.
That is not the way it is today. The NDP might want to go back but the world will not. The change that is around us in every country of the world today will not stop simply because an out of date politician or an out of date political party puts forward an out of date motion. The importance of this debate is that we have an opportunity to explain why this motion is out of date and is wrong.
What would happen if tomorrow morning the Government of Canada notified the Government of the United States that it was going to abrogate the free trade agreement? Let us be ruthless, let us do it tomorrow. What would be the impact if we did it tomorrow? What would we achieve and what kind of situation would we face at that time?
Yes, there is some superficial attraction to this. Take the Honda case. Abrogation would solve it. In one sense there would no longer be duty free entry for Honda cars into the United States. There would be no problem in interpreting the U.S.-Canada rules of origin, but it would not do much for Honda and it would not do that much for the 1,400 workers that Honda employs in Ontario. Honda would immediately become liable for the duties being disputed. Every car shipped from Canada into the United States would pay the U.S. duty and every part coming from the United States to Canada would have to pay close to a 10 per cent duty.
It would not take long for Honda to put two and two together and move their Alliston plant down to Ohio. But our dispute with U.S. customs would be over and we would have some peace of mind in our relationship with the United States, but no more jobs. The jobs would be gone. It would be the same for every other company which has invested in Canada to tap into the United States market.
Things would also become a lot clearer in the softwood lumber file. It is incredible that this motion would be put by a B.C. member of Parliament. The government of British Columbia and the industry in British Columbia were very aggressive in wanting us to terminate the memorandum of understanding on softwood lumber.
Where would we be without the FTA if we were still in the softwood lumber dispute? We would not have an opportunity to challenge any decision through the dispute settlement process. The U.S. Department of Commerce, the U.S. International Trade Commission could stop worrying about their decisions being reviewed by the free trade panel. They could go back to the old way, the way it was done in 1986 without the binational review. We would not have to refer them to a panel made up of Canadians and Americans who would judge this in an objective way. Things might not work out as well for the Canadian lumber workers in his province, but at least the NDP members would have the satisfaction of knowing that they would no longer have to blame it all on the free trade agreement.
Let us not forget about the pork decision last year. The pork decision resulted in pork producers being paid back about $20 million in duties because of the actions of the free trade panel. Is my hon. friend suggesting that we
May 11, 1992

should just scrap these panels? If he is, what he is saying is that the pork producers would continue to pay, year in and year out, those $20 million of duties.
If the free trade agreement were scrapped tomorrow, what would be the first thing the pork producers would do in the United States? They would initiate another countervailing duty action and the Government of the United States, the International Trade Commission, would not have to worry about another panel. They could just go ahead and do what they did last year and our pork producers would be caught. They would have to start paying duties again and put in jeopardy about $500 million worth of trade between the United States and Canada. But the NDP would be satisfied. They would have peace of mind because we would not have a free trade agreement.

Cancelling the FTA would probably not encourage the United States to be more accommodating on beer or anything else. So far, I find nothing good in the idea of cancelling the FTA. Let us look at the other side of the coin. Would it create new problems? Let me mention some of them. My mail would certainly swell when tens of thousands of Canadian business people and professionals who have to go to the United States would learn that the provisions of chapter 15 allowing them to stay there temporarily no longer apply.
More than 60 categories of professionals who now travel effortlessly back and forth across the border would once again have to stand in line and fill in long forms before travelling to the United States for business purposes.
Canadian engineers, consultants, astronomers, graphic designers, architects, pharmacists, physiotherapists, chemists, geologists, urban planners, these professionals would all be frustrated in their efforts to serve their customers in the United States market. They would lose business to their detriment and to that of the Canadian
Supply
economy. What purpose would be served by undoing what, by all accounts, has been a resounding success?
There would be the question of unravelling the tariff cuts which have been implemented to date, many of which were accelerated at the request of business on both sides of the border. Thousands of Canadian businesses have restructured to serve the broader North American market and they would have to revise their business plans. Where would they be when the tariff reverted to the old levels, as they must under the GATT?
They would find themselves competing in the U.S. market on the same basis as the rest of the world. A quick check of the trade statistics indicates that while Canadian exports to the United States grew over the last three years, largely as a result of the free trade agreement and despite the recession, U.S. imports from the rest of the world had declined.
Canadian companies have improved their import share because U.S. tariffs on Canadian products have been down while those of other countries have remained at the same level. It is not a good sign for companies that are heavily dependent on the United States market. That increase in exports of $5 billion translates into about 75,000 or 80,000 jobs, jobs that we would not have if exports had stayed at the same level.
Abrogation of the free trade agreement would likely bring about a reversal in the inflow of foreign direct investment. The first three years under the FTA saw a remarkable level of consumer investor confidence as both Canadian and foreign companies took steps to make Canada the base for their North American operations. That also means jobs to us.
Proctor and Gamble, for example, restructured its North American operations so that the U.S. plants now specialize in longer production runs while the Canadian company, a more specialized type of company, has access to the product mandates for speciality products for the whole of the North American market.
That is the kind of rational long-term planning that would have to be reversed if we decided to abrogate the free trade agreement.
Similarly would Gandalf, GTE Sylvania, Heron Cable, Hughes Aircraft, Kodak, and Polymer International, to name but a few, reconsider their decision to rationalize

May 11, 1992
Supply
production and serve the North American market from Canada?
Would Dow Chemical, Cargill Limited, E.D. Smith, Dupont, Rubbermaid, Cameo, Nikon Optical, Ganong Brothers and the dozens of other companies that have expanded facilities in Canada to serve the North American market change their minds?
Check these companies, Mr. Speaker. Their decisions have strengthened and enlarged their presence in Canada and made the jobs of their employees more secure.
Would the hundreds of Canadian companies that are showing every day that they can compete in the U.S. market now that the barriers are down continue to put their resources on the line if the U.S. tariff reductions were reversed?
They are successfully competing as the $110 billion in exports to the United States attest every day. How well would they do if the United States again treated us like the rest of the world and raised those tariffs?
Could our exporters rely on other markets? Does anyone opposite seriously think that our trading partners would not worry about the stability of a country that walks away from a trade agreement of the scope and importance of the free trade agreement? What kind of message does that send out to the rest of the world? Putting aside the fact that other countries would give their eye teeth for the kind of access that we enjoy to the United States market, what does abrogation say about our reliability as a trade and investment partner?

The New Democratic Party has its lists of companies that closed down. It continually repeats how many Canadians are looking for work or lost their job in the last few years. I know these figures. They are precisely the figures which keep me, as Minister for International Trade and Minister of Industry, trying relentlessly to meet the challenge that they present.
But instead of wringing my hands and blaming the FTA, I look for solutions-real solutions instead of imaginary ones. In working with Canadians to find solutions, I am encouraged by the many success stories reported to me. They may not make headlines, but they are nonetheless real.

Let me just give one example of this. Sit-Rite Products makes high-end furniture. It decided to consolidate its activities in Mississauga and close its facilities in Atlanta. It is a decision the company does not regret. It has been good for its employees, good for its suppliers, and good for its customers. That company did it because Mississauga offered a good site from which to serve the whole North American market. It made sense because the borders were open.
If the answer to Canada's economic difficulties lies in closing our borders and handing out subsidies, I would not hesitate to recommend that route to my colleagues. But the bitter experience of the past few years is proof positive that is the road to disaster. The companies that are closing and the jobs that we are losing are companies and jobs that could not adjust to meet the tough reality of a global economy. I take no satisfaction in making that point, but it is a point that we must never forget.
It is not difficult to find examples around the world of economies that chose autarchy and the disaster that followed. Every trade minister I meet who visits Canada from Latin America is eager to tell us the tale of woe that flowed from years of closed borders. Next week at the OECD I will be meeting trade ministers from Sweden to New Zealand, from Austria to Australia, and they will emphasize the need to keep markets open and to negotiate new and better trade rules.
Australia and New Zealand have a free trade area. Sweden and Austria, not large countries, are both applying to join the European Community. Yes, they will face tougher competition. Yes, some of their companies will suffer. So why do they do it? It is because their companies will become tougher competitors and they will have access to greater market opportunities, precisely what Canadian companies have under the free trade agreement.
No, this government is not going to follow the counsel of despair that permeates the resolution before us today. We will stay the course, the course that I outlined in 1984 as Minister of Finance which is gradually turning this country around. We are trying to create an economy with a future, a future attuned to the real world in which we find ourselves today.
May 11, 1992

Last week I was in Munster, Germany to consider how we can bring the shattered economies of central and eastern Europe into the global trading system. What is the objective of most of these countries? It is to join the European Economic Community, reduce their tariffs, and open up their economies to greater competition. They want to join the real world. They want to reject the past. It is sad that the NDP policy is to embrace the past. The discussion was a vivid reminder of the error of excessive government intervention. It also served to impress upon me once again the tremendous and important opportunities we have in Canada if we organize ourselves to take on the world.
To get there, we need a policy mix that rewards private initiative and that encourages our entrepreneurs to look to the future with confidence both inside as well as outside Canada.
Canada has a proud tradition as a trading nation. Our current prosperity, our wealth as a nation and our ability to promote the best quality of life in the world is in large measure the product of our success as world traders.
The key to the transition we are facing does not lie in government programs and regulations. It lies in the imagination, initiative and industriousness of Canadians in Toronto, Montreal, Vancouver, Lunenburg, Bathurst, Nanaimo, Drumheller, Rosetown and Rimouski. Across this vast land Canadians are determined to prove that yes, they can compete.
We have been working hard with companies, trying to ensure that they have the opportunity to compete and the access they need to the rest of the world. This is why we negotiated the free trade agreement, why we have negotiated the NAFTA, and why we are aggressively working to see a successful conclusion of the Uruguay round.
Our trade offices around the world are all dedicated to one objective. If there is an opportunity out there for a Canadian company, we want to make sure that Canadian company knows about it and gets the sale.
Finally, we must defend the access that we have gained and ensure that no Canadian company loses a sale because of lack of government effort. That is why we work hard to keep good relations with our trading partners. That is why we spare no effort to advance the
Supply
interests of Canadian entrepreneurs. Our best weapon in defending those interests is a good trade agreement.
The FTA is by far the best way to deal with hard-nosed American protectionism. Make no mistake, the Americans can be difficult. Honda, softwood lumber, magnesium or pork; you it name it, they have tried it. We fought each one very hard. Without the FTA life would be even tougher, but what if we did not have an FTA? What if we did not allow for this opening up of our economy?
We would be protected for a while. We would not be exposed to as much change, but would the change stop outside Canada? No, it would not. The change would continue because no one is going to stop the world and allow Canada to get on again. When we finally did open up as most other countries are doing now, the adjustment would be that much greater.
We cannot hide from the world today, but don't just take my word for it. Listen to B.C. Premier Mike Harcourt. Last week, he said:
Our government means business-We have to prepare for the
global economy. We cannot prepare for it by building walls around
ourselves.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the minister for quoting Mr. Harcourt. Mr. Harcourt is talking about opening new markets, different deals than the one we are stuck with, and more common sense in making agreements.
I want to talk about the alternatives, but before I do that I want to comment on a couple of things the minister said. He left the impression that somehow, if the free trade agreement were abrogated, the auto pact would be gone. Let us understand what we had before we signed the free trade agreement. The terms and conditions of the auto pact were as follows. Duty-free access to the United States is predicated on the fact that vehicles must come from Canada and vehicles must contain at least 50 per cent North American content.

Supply
Duty-free access to Canada is predicated on the fact that manufacturers must locate in Canada, manufacturers must maintain at least a 75 per cent ratio of production value of vehicles made in Canada to net Canadian sales, and the manufacturers' amount of Canadian value added for all classes of vehicles in Canada must be at least as great as the amount achieved in 1964.
This is a sectoral agreement that has been in practice to the benefit of both countries lo these many years. There is absolutely nothing in the free trade agreement that says if we would abrogate the free trade agreement the auto pact would be abrogated as well.
That is a fabrication. I hope the minister did not attempt to leave that impression with this House or with the Canadian people. This sectoral agreement was there before the free trade agreement and will last after the abrogation of the free trade agreement.
My good friend the minister said they had these great sales into the United States. Everything is relative. I repeat, in 1985 to 1988 the Canadian average annual $4.7 billion surplus in trade with the United States was in goods, services and dividends. No matter how much it increased in Canada, it increased dramatically more in the United States' favour. The minister avoids making that comparison.
I repeat that surplus turned into a $2.4 billion deficit in 1989, a $0.4 billion deficit in 1990, and reached a $3.1 billion deficit in 1991, three years after the free trade agreement. No matter how much both sides increased, we decreased from our surplus.
The minister also mentioned the Honda case. He said what my friend the spokesperson for the New Democratic Party is saying, that it would frighten off investors. It is important to deal with that. In the Honda case the U.S. is charging that the majority of the value of cars made in Alliston, Ontario by Honda actually comes from Japan due to the value of the auto parts imported into Canada from Japan. The U.S. is sending a message to foreign auto makers, and who got the message? Well, Korean trade attache Myeng Keun Ha said: "Future Korean investment in Canada will end if the U.S. harassment does not. It will be safer to invest directly in the United States".
This is not the New Democratic Party saying this. This is an offshore trade official saying they will not invest in Canada if the harassment continues, contrary to the pious wishes of the minister.
In conclusion, I would like to quote from Mr. Gordon Ritchie in an essay in The Wall Street Journal. For the edification of the minister, Mr. Gordon Ritchie was one of the principal architects of this deal. He said in consequence to the American reaction to Canada's protest of the U.S. countervailing duties on Canadian softwood lumber: "Senior officials in the Bush administration have hinted the U.S. may refuse to be bound by the decision of the binational panels or may even refuse to allow the case to go before them. This would be tantamount to tearing up the free trade agreement".
If the Americans do not get their own way, Mr. Ritchie is saying, there is some suspicion they will go about it by bullying and threatening, in effect tearing up the deal anyway.
On the last comment on the EC, nonsense. The minister knows very well that the European Community is made up of relatively the same size population and countries with varying degrees of economic development: the poor regions of the south coming into the richer regions of the north, all under a social contract protecting workers conditions, the environment and other areas. There is nothing like that, when the minister talks about Latin America, coming from Mexico. Even today's newspapers point out there is no protection.
I say to the minister that point by point he has lost his argument.

Mr. Speaker, let me respond to some of these outrageous statements that my hon. friend has made. Let us talk about the trade statistics. In the trade statistics, as I indicated clearly, we have increased our exports into the United States' market. The rest of the world's exports into the United States have dropped. In other words, we have benefited by the free trade agreement in relation to other countries trading into the United States' market.

My hon. friend refers to the trade surplus. The part of our trade surplus that is covered by the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement, goods and services-not interest, dividends and tourism-is up about $1.5 billion since the free trade agreement came in.
The next point he refers to is statements by Gordon Ritchie. In this case, I agree with my hon. friend and I agree with Gordon Ritchie. If the U.S. did not allow any decision on softwood lumber to go to the binational dispute settlement panels, that would indeed be a very serious thing. I just do not believe that will happen and we will see what happens in time.
My hon. friend referred to the European Community, countries relatively the same size going into the European Community: Luxembourg of 1.5 million people is right next door to Germany, a country of now 75 million people; Belgium and France, Belgium with about 10 million people against France with 50 million to 55 million people. My hon. friend lost that point as well.
The final point that I will speak to is the Honda issue. My hon. friend says the auto pact is not part of the free trade agreement. I appreciate him saying that because that is contrary to what his colleagues have been saying for the last three years. Honda is not a part of the auto pact, so it would be governed by the ordinary rules of trade. If there is no free trade agreement, it would be covered by the ordinary rules of trade. It would not have the benefit of access to the United States market under the auto pact because it is not a member of the auto pact.
The thing that just astounds me every time I hear the NDP stand up and talk about the tremendous benefits of the auto pact is going back to the late sixties, we find that for three, four, five years the hon. member's party was blindly critical of the auto pact, saying that it was going to ruin our automotive industry and yes, there were some difficult times there.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, on a recent trip to Japan I had my first opportunity to see the unique Japanese institution called sumo wrestling where great behemoths of 300 or 400 pounds get together in a very small ring, clasp arms around one another and shake their jowls and move until one sort of falls over.
I thought that was a unique Japanese institution until I came to the House of Commons today and witnessed the debate between the hon. member from Esquimalt and the minister of trade. Here is our own re-enactment of sumo wrestling, two behemoths, overweight, overstuffed, sort of standing together stationary in entrenched positions being unable to understand that the world, the time and thinking must move on.
I am here to present what I think is a more effective and realistic position on the kind of trade initiative and the kind of trade program that Canada must consider.
Let us first take into account a certain false premise that the minister of trade injects into every single debate. He equates the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement with open free trade as if it is the only kind that is at all possible. We know he is wrong. There is the GATT for example based upon multilateral principles, where there are common rules and some common institutions and in which the tariffs have come down more substantially under the GATT than they did under the free trade agreement. There was greater movement after the Tokyo round of GATT negotiations to bring tariffs down between Canada and the United States than there has been under the free trade agreement. But the question is, what price was paid?
Under multilateral negotiations where there is a large number of countries in negotiation you do not have to go on a one-to-one bargaining relationship with a country 10 times your size. There is a way of pooling risk, pooling negotiating leverage and pooling bargaining power so that there can be shared benefits and shared costs.
There is also the auto pact, which is another form of opening up trade, but the key there is in the form of a managed trade agreement where the parties to the agreement, in this case both the United States and Canada, build in safeguards to ensure that employment would stay in their respective countries. If it did not stay in those respective countries they could change that

May 11, 1992
Supply
agreement, they could bring the tariffs back. It was designed to ensure that employment in certain key sectors would remain.
There is also the European Economic Community which is quite a different model of free trade than what we have under the FTA. It was organized on very different principles, whether it would be some supema-tional organizations. It began on a sector by sector basis where there is a pooling of risk and a pooling of capital. Over time it was also a clear agreement that under the European Economic Community the parties to the agreement would also make joint decisions. There would be common law and common codes, none of which appears under the Canada free trade agreement. The fact of the matter is that the FTA has far less to do about bringing down tariffs and opening up trade than it does about putting handcuffs on the Canadian government and its ability to provide a management role in the economy.
The real story of the Canada free trade agreement was told to me across a dinner table by the chief negotiator, Mr. Reisman, where he admitted that the whole purpose of this is to make sure that governments in Canada would not be able to operate a mixed economy, but would be able to support the free market flows. In other words, it was far more an ideological document fitting in with the broad philosophy of the present government and its business corporate allies than it was a document trying to honestly analyse what is in the best interest of Canada.
The hard reality is in order to get the bargain this government gave up substantial powers in order to manage its economy and I would suggest to enable us to meet trade challenges in a much more competitive global environment.
The FTA is a continental trade agreement designed primarily to eliminate, reduce or to handcuff the activity of government institutions in Canada as a way of ensuring that the kind of economy we designed over the years would be eliminated and there would be a laissez-faire open market system in which government could not hold large corporations accountable. That is the real essence of the free trade agreement and that is why we are paying a price today.
Canadians in the past were never concerned about reducing some tariffs. We did it from 1948, the beginning
of the GATT, right through. At the same time there were governments in power that understood that there is dislocation when tariffs are reduced. Certain industries are affected and there were special programs brought in. I remember things like the Canadian Industrial Renewal Board to deal with things like the shoewear and the textile areas to help them retool, modernize and to deal with worker dislocation. There was a real dedicated effort to come to grips with the adjustments that were required, not by some phoney program of getting the federal government out of training by turning it over to the unemployment insurance contributions of the employer and the employees, the federal government abdicating its total role and cutting back its own commitments to training, which is one of the great fallacies that this government likes to perpetrate.
The reason I mentioned the different models of trade relations is because it has a very important bearing on what you do with the FTA. You have to analyse what the problem is in order to come up with the right answer. Before we do that, it is also important to deal with some of the phoney statistics used by the minister of trade, the Prime Minister and others as they try to convince Canadians of the unconvincable, that the free trade agreement is working. I suppose you do not have to go much further than the inherent wisdom of the Canadian people. In the last survey I saw, about 65 or 70 per cent were opposed to the FTA. Why? Because they know brothers, cousins and sisters and mothers who have lost jobs, who have seen their factories moved as a direct consequence of it.
The minister keeps saying: "Well, out trade is improving". Is it? Let us have a more accurate analysis drawn from the Bank of Canada Department of Finance's own figures. The three year merchandise trade surplus of Canada from 1986 to 1988 was $31.5 billion. From 1989 to 1991, it was down to $26.5 billion.
Canada's three year current account balance with the United States, not just the merchandise balance but the entire balance, all the invisibles, the dividends, the transfer payments between corporations was over a three year period from 1986 to 1988 plus $10.6 billion. Since 1988 and the free trade agreement, it is minus $10.8 billion. Is that a record of success? Is that a great demonstration of the effectiveness of the free trade agreement's ability to generate wealth?

:

May 11, 1992

In 1991 we had a minus $300 million current account balance with the United States compared to 1984 when they took over the government of a plus $6.7 billion surplus on current accounts. How can the Minister for International Trade, with any degree of honesty, any degree of accountability to the Canadian people get up and keep saying: "The thing is working" when in fact it has gone from a $6.7 billion surplus to a minus $300 million deficit. Is that the accomplishment the minister really likes to talk about? Is that the great success story he likes to parade across the country? If it is, he has turned the world upside down. He has been using inverted logic and funny-money economics. He really belongs with the Reform Party and its curious form of economic mathematics. He certainly does not belong in the role of minister of trade who has some responsibility.
Let us deal with one of the other canards that keeps being thrown in. The minister for trade throws in examples. I listened to his speech and he said: "Well, this factory, General Electric, I think is going to give us a world product mandate". It was not the first time, by the way. There were times before 1984 when world product mandates were done in negotiation with the Government of Canada and others.
What is happening is that IBM, Canada's largest computer firm by the way, just last Friday announced that all its marketing, all its research, all of its head office activity, its accounting is moving back to its head office in the United States with the loss of several thousand jobs along with it. That story has been repeated every single day across this country. There is not a constituency in this country that has not had to hold a graveyard ceremony for its lost industries: not layoffs, not jobs that will come back, but jobs that have moved south of the border.
I can say this. When we were discussing and debating the free trade agreement, the warning we offered at that time was that the specific kind of agreement negotiated by this minister and others would lead to a form of harmonization, where the pressure would be on to bring our tax laws, our environmental standards, our labour standards down to the lower level, unlike the European Economic Community which requires countries to go the highest level not the lowest level. As a result, I can point to firms in my own constituency which, faced with a cost
Supply
problem, were basically forced to say: "Well, if I move to Tennessee there is no minimum wage. If I move to Texas there is no environmental code or labour standards". Therefore, if they get a marginal degree of interest on their costs from a balance sheet point of view it may make sense. From the point of view of the economy of the country, it is a disaster. It means a total, complete wipe-out of those jobs. There is nothing built into the FTA to deal with that fundamental problem.
I can recall that during the period of 1986, 1987 and 1988, debating with this minister in the House and asking:. "What would be built into the free trade agreement to take into account the appreciation of the dollar?" At the time, the U.S. Treasurer, who was Mr. Baker at the time, kept saying that one of the American agendas was to get its trading partners to bring up the level of their dollar in order to help bring down the U.S. trade deficit.
The then Minister of Finance said: "Oh, don't worry about it. It won't happen. It will never occur".
Since that time the Canadian dollar has appreciated by 16 per cent and as a result we have lost close to $24 billion of exports. That is the problem. There was nothing built into that agreement to take into account that whatever benefit that we might accrue as a result of a 2 per cent or 3 per cent reduction in tariffs we would lose by a 16 per cent appreciation in the dollar.
Do not tell me that was not part of the understanding that went along with the FTA. It was not written in the agreement. The minister may scoff but can he deny that the dollar has appreciated by 16 per cent since 1984, and that as a result we have been haemorrhaging a large number of our manufacturing jobs along the way?
There is clear evidence and that is the difference.
In 1988 we were debating what was hypothetical. They said it was going to be good, there were going to be jobs and economic growth, and salvation would be at hand. Elmer Gantry, otherwise known as the Prime Minister, went on the preaching pulpit across the country, supported by the corporate sector and a $10 million ad campaign, saying: "If you sign the agreement your hair will grow, the warts will go off your hands, there will be milk and honey pouring in downtown and on Bay Street, everyone will be happy". Who could say no or yes.

Supply
We said that we saw problems and difficulties, and we set conditions, but there was no hard evidence.
The evidence is in. Four hundred thousand jobs have been lost and a million and a half people are unemployed.
Mr. Speaker, can you believe the statement of the minister in this debate in which he said: "We really are on the right track". Can you believe it? He is a minister of the Crown who, I hope, read the statistics that came out last Friday about the net loss of jobs. In my own province of Manitoba there has been a net loss of 17,000 jobs over the last two years.
Yet he is saying: "Hey, folks, we are on the right track". The right track to hell is where this government is taking us. It is taking us right down the road to decline as a country. Part of the reason is because it surrendered without a fight, without negotiations, the ability of the Government of Canada to be able to effectively manage its own economy.
Let me give a quick list of the things that we gave: U.S. national treatment rights to Canada's exports under article 105; tariff-free entry for U.S. processed dairy, poultry, and egg products, which is leading to the decline of the marketing boards; we relinquished Canada's right to use minimum export price requirements which meant that in the fish processing dispute with the United States we could not use that method as a way of protecting our fish processing industry; we relinquished Canada's right to levy export taxes; and harmonization with the U.S. of Canadian standards and related procedures for agricultural food and beverages which, as one of my colleagues pointed out in the House last week, means that substandard meat is being imported into Canada at this very time.
I have a whole page of things that were given away in exchange for that tariff reduction, which we had been successful in negotiating over the years under the GATT anyway.
Let me deal for a moment with the real question. There is no question that the free trade agreement is not working in the economic, social, or political interests of this country.
To cap that off, allow me to mention an interesting study released by OECD on Friday which pointed out that U.S. exports to Third World countries have increased more than any other country in the OECD.
Canada has declined, we have actually been losing our exports. The figure was at one time close to 13 per cent of our exports and is now down to 7 per cent.
It points out that our ability to mount an effective diversified export trade program in a world which is becoming far more pluralized has been lost. Our ability to target certain industries and to deal with certain programs that will allow us to open up marketing around the world as it becomes more pluralized and more diversified is being lost.
By every indicator-Japan, the Pacific, Latin America, and European communities-our exports are declining, partly because of the obsessive preoccupation of this government with the U.S. market. That is all it sees. That is where it puts all the resources. It is also partly because we have lost the ability of a Government of Canada to put in place the kind of policies and programs that would allow us a more diversified, pluralistic, and export-led trade program.
Another question is: "What do we do about it?" My friend from the NDP was less than complimentary about the fact that we have said that our position is to renegotiate.
First, let us understand a little history. I think the hon. minister recognizes that I was here when the history was made so I know something about it. Prior to the free trade agreement, in fact in 1987, our own party put out a very specific policy paper. I have it here in front of me if it needs to be tabled.
We said that any negotiations with the United States on free trade must meet certain conditions, and we set about 12 conditions. However, only two of them were met. It was on that basis that we rejected the FTA, particularly because it gave away the store, it gave away the farm, the factory and the transportation industry. It gave away our social safety net and probably eventually it will give away our water.
We are saying: "We still believe the free trade agreement is not working in the economic interests of this country, and we still believe, as we did then, that it was a bad deal". The question is what to do about it now. It has been in effect for four years. Some of the changes are already in place, some of the tariffs are already coming down.
May 11, 1992

If you abrogate it, then do we wipe those changes out and go through a readjustment? As Winston Churchill once said: "Once you have written it, you have to rewrite it". The fact of the matter is that there are certain problems.
Second, my friend from the NDP, who is an objective judge of good policy, knows that there is a certain requirement under international law on to deal with treaties. Unfortunately, It has now been signed into law, but during the election campaign his leader spent the last two weeks attacking us rather than the government, which he should not have done.
As a result, we did not get the number of seats in the House that would have meant that the agreement would not have gone through. Nevertheless it signed the agreement. Therefore, under international rules, it must be treated with a procedure and process that recognizes certain basic responsibilities and obligations under international law. One would be to at least give the Americans the right to say that they do not want to renegotiate.
Is that an unreasonable stand? My colleague asked the member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca if he had an answer about what his own leader said. Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased once again to offer some rebuttal to the minuet of false pretensions of the Minister for International Trade. He is more skilled at dancing on his toes than he is at telling the truth.
He says: "Well, things are still getting better". Let us just use the last complete year. At $103 billion, domestic exports to the United States were down $2.1 billion the last year. Let us look at what constitute our exports. I will tell the House where we are losing our trade with the United States. Motor vehicle engines and parts, truck tractors, chassis, and various forms of equipment are down 19.1 per cent. What is up? Crude petroleum. We are again shipping off our raw resources with no
value added, no job content, in exchange for the more heavily mechanized heavy equipment development in the industry. It is no wonder we are losing manufacturing jobs.
If this is a minister who is satisfied with Canada becoming a hewer of wood and a drawer of water, if that is the Tory economic policy, then it is no wonder that the Canadian people are just waiting for the moment when they can turf them out on their ears. The fact of the matter is that Canadians want to be highly competitive, they want to have a highly sophisticated economy. They do not want to be using up our valuable natural resources in exchange for lost service manufacturing jobs.
This minister who knows no equal when it comes to making this world safe for euphemisms was able to say: "We have added to the social safety net". Let us look at how the government has done that. It has totally abdicated and withdrawn from any responsibility in the unemployment insurance fund. It has turned over the entire funding to the employers and the employees, which means that it now excludes young people who are not eligible for unemployment insurance, women who are coming back into the work force, and people who have exhausted their benefits. There are two and three-year waiting lists for those training programs. This is a government that says: "Look at what a wonderful job we are doing".
It has carved more holes in the social safety net than the Spaniards have fishing nets off the east coast on the Grand Banks, where we are losing all that cod.
The fact is that the free trade agreement, based on a hard-nosed analysis, is not working in the economic interests of this country. The government has done nothing to provide any response to it, no adjustment program and no attempt to renegotiate.
Even worse, it is repeating the same mistake. One would think that after you had hit your country between the eyes with a two-by-four you might ease off a little. However, the government is now down there negotiating the same kind of deal with the same kind of people. It is going to make the same botch of it because it does not understand the importance of ensuring that in this competitive world there is a government in place that knows how to stand up for Canadians, to preserve our independence, and work to ensure that there is an effective government working for Canadians rather than working against them.

speechtext:
Thank you, Mr. Speaker.
The amendment which the Liberal Party has moved today points out the differences which exist in trying to deal with the devastation which has hit this country as a consequence of the free trade deal.
There is an approach that says: "Let's recognize this devastation. Let's recognize the causes of it and let's talk about doing something different, about taking a different approach. Let's replace the free trade deal with a new economic strategy that does not make us dependent on the United States, that does not tie ourselves in with all sorts of giveaways which we have given to the United States in the free trade deal". That is the approach of the New Democratic Party.
Then there is the approach of the Liberal Party. It says: "We are not quite sure but we think that we can renegotiate this", without ever indicating what would be renegotiated.
The United States has indicated what it would like to renegotiate. It would like to renegotiate so that some of the protections for Canadian culture are done away with. Perhaps that is what the Liberal Party wants to renegotiate, perhaps it wants to give that to the United States.
Supply
The United States has said that it wants to renegotiate the auto pact. Various members of congress in the United States have said that they want to see a change in that free trade agreement so that the safeguards Canadians have in the auto pact, which ensure that there is Canadian content, are done away with. Perhaps the Liberals want to sit down with the Americans to renegotiate and do away with that.
The United States has also said that Canada got away with far too much in the free trade agreement in terms of intellectual property rights. It has said that there should be much more constraint, it should be much more difficult for Canada to take a different approach than the United States. Perhaps that is what the Liberals want to renegotiate.
Those are the things that the United States has made clear it wants to see changed. All we can assume is that is what the Liberals want to see changed as well, because the Liberals are not prepared to tell us what their bottom line is. They are prepared to say to the people of Canada: "Yes, yes, do not worry. We are going to renegotiate. You can rest assured".
Canadians are cautious people. Canadians like to think that it might be possible, despite the fact that the person who negotiated this deal with the Americans was the key economic advisor to the Liberal leader. I am talking about Simon Reisman.
Simon Reisman was the key economic adviser to the member for Vancouver Quadra when he was leader of the Liberal Party. That member subsequently took such a strong position against that trade deal because it was not negotiated properly, as his Liberal party now says.
The Liberal Party was advised by Simon Reisman for years. The Liberals made Simon Reisman the Deputy Minister of Finance, the most powerful position in the bureaucracy of this country. He went down and negotiated a treaty and came back and said: "Boy, have we taken those Americans to the cleaners. They are virtually a Third World country in terms of negotiating skill when it comes to dealing with us from Canada".
Now we hear the Liberals say that despite this magnificent Liberal adviser who led the negotiating team, despite this magnificent Liberal appointee who had been Deputy Minister of Finance, despite the great skill that Simon Reisman was supposed to have demonstrated to generations of Liberals, despite all that it will somehow be possible to renegotiate. They are saying that through

May 11, 1992
Supply
renegotiations it will be possible to make everything right.
It is certainly true that there are still some people in this country who believe in fairy tales. There are still some people who believe that over the rainbow everything is going to be beautiful. There are still people who think that in the end everything turns out right no matter what. They are morality believers. They really think that the world is a wonderful and good place and all of us simply have to sit down together and we will work out something just superb.
This is exactly the same Liberal Party that gets up day after day in this House of Commons and says that the Americans are not even respecting the present spirit of the free trade deal. They say: "They are not respecting the spirit of the deal but we are going to sit them down and good old Canada, the boy scout of the world, will prove to the United States the error of its ways. We are going to prove to the United States that all you have to do is smile and chuckle and, my goodness, life will be wonderful once more".
It is quite possible, listening to the Leader of the Opposition, that he actually believes that if he sits down with the President of the United States and he throws away his notes, as he likes to throw away his speech notes, it will be possible for the very force of his personality to persuade the United States that all these terrible attacks, against the spirit of the free trade deal which the Liberals attack, will somehow disappear.
Mr. Speaker, it is also possible that you will turn into Santa Claus and give everyone in this country a new car in their driveway. It is quite possible the Minister of Finance will actually turn into someone who cares about unemployed people in this country. That too is possible. Saul on the road to Damascus did after all have a magnificent conversion. However, it is a precedent that we have not seen repeated many times in the continuing history of our world.
I say to the House and the people of Canada that anyone who believes the Liberals when they say that: "Yes, there is good will on the part of the United States.
All we have to do is renegotiate it. We just have to say those words and because we are Liberals, after all, George Bush will sit down like a lamb and sign away everything which the Americans fought so hard to get and got in that past free trade deal".
This is not just pie in the sky on the part of the Liberal Party. It is fundamentally dishonest on the part of the Liberal Party to stand in this House of Commons and attack the United States for breaking the spirit of the free trade deal, attack the United States for being aggressive and tough in international trade, and then say: "We will be able to sit down with them and we will be able to sort it all out".
Of course, it is the kind of pie in the sky that Canadians would like to believe in. All Canadians across this country would like to believe in gingerbread houses in the middle of the haunted forest. We have all read the stories. However, the world is not like that.
Unfortunately, the Liberal Party has lost touch with the reality of the world. The Liberal Party has been out of power at the federal level so much and has proved itself so inept in power at the provincial level that it no longer has the capacity to see the world as it is. It sees the world instead as it would like it to be. It sees a world of fantasy figures, a world of good witches of the west who will come sweeping brilliantly down on to the stage and make everything right. It is dishonest. It is not just dishonest, it also begs the fundamental question when we start talking about the trade deal.
Canadians believe that we should not be in that trade deal as it is presently constituted. The vast, vast majority of Canadians believe that, and they are right. They have seen what the trade deal has done to this country. They also know realistically that if we are going to get out of the trade deal there have to be alternatives. There has to be a new strategy, a new direction and a new approach that we take. The Liberals by saying: "Well, all we have to do is we just have to sit down and talk" are avoiding facing that tough question of what the alternatives are. They are avoiding answering in a responsible way the question that surely any party that wants to govern must answer, and that is: What will you do instead of pursuing the free trade deal?
May 11, 1992

I do not think the answer is easy. I do not think there are easy answers to that question. That is why when we move our position today on this opposition day we do it with seriousness and we do it with a depth of conviction. We also do it with a considerable sense of just how serious a step this will be for Canada to take to move out of the free trade arrangement. There are no easy answers, but there are answers.
I think the answers are that we have to reverse direction, not just on the free trade deal but in three key areas: the free trade deal, the GST and the way in which we have kept our interest rates so much higher than those in the United States.
There seem to me to be seven steps in such a strategy. The first is that we have to recognize that a relatively small economy like Canada must have safeguards in its trade relations with a much larger economy like the United States. The auto pact, for instance, has been a great success in Canadian trade politics because it dealt with one broad sector and because it gave safeguards to Canadian producers. We have to look at other areas where it is possible to have deals like the auto pact.
Second, we have got to get rid of the GST. We have to replace it, not with a new manufacturers' sales tax or some kind of national sales tax on consumers, as the Liberals talk about sometimes. Instead it is time to put a fair tax system into place where we eliminate some of the unfair, unjust loopholes that exist, where we put into effect some of the taxes which work well in the United States, like a minimum corporate tax, where we restore some measure of progressive fairness in the income tax system itself.
Third, we have to focus on interest rates. We have got to see to it that they are no more than 1.5 percentage points higher than in the United States. That can be achieved by our Bank of Canada, but we have to recognize that this means a lower value for the Canadian dollar, probably in the 75 cent to 77 cent range.
Fourth, to make this strategy work, it is critical that the federal government keep tight control on the national deficit. In the view of the federal New Democrat caucus, which discussed this issue very carefully in planning our response to the past budget, Canada has reached a point with 35 cents of every tax dollar going for interest on the national debt where we must not increase the national deficit. To do so while carrying through major policy
Supply
changes like a withdrawal from the free trade agreement would be a recipe for disaster.
Fifth, we have to take federal initiatives to get people back to work and to improve our work force. To do so, given concern about the deficit, means we must reallocate money in the national budget. That reallocation can come from less defence spending, from fewer government departments and cabinet ministers and from a new approach that streamlines the host of different agencies that now hand out money to corporations for regional development. A single regional development bank that loans money instead of giving it away would make much more sense.
Sixth, we need an economic recovery fund in this country, organized like similar investment pools in Europe with the co-operation of business, labour and government. This national fund would attract money from the private sector as in Europe from RRSPs, pension funds, and mutual funds. This pool of capital would then be available to build up and modernize key parts of Canada's industrial sector.
Seventh, finally, for the community and small business level of our economy, we need a community economic development strategy in this country. We have spent a good deal of time talking with community economic development groups across this country who have shown us what exciting initiatives can take place at the local level to get people back at work if the money is available for those groups on a consistent, continuing basis.
Over all it is possible to replace the trade deal with a new economic strategy of the kind I am talking about. But we cannot do that until we face reality and facing reality means recognizing that this is not a world of fairy tales. This is not a world, as the Liberal Party would like us to believe, where everything is coming up roses and Canada is just going to get its way by smiling sweetly. We have to face the need to very clearly and specifically say to Canadians that we are going to get out of this trade deal. We are going to replace it with a new economic strategy. We are not going to get lost in the never, never land of long, tedious negotiations with the United States which will give us nothing in terms of benefits, create tremendous uncertainties in this country and be fundamentally dishonest so far as the people of Canada are concerned.

May 11, 1992

Mr. Speaker, in listening to the speech of the NDP member for Essex-Windsor as well as that of the member for Esquimau-Juan de Fuca earlier, I have a sense of deja vu of the 1988 election campaign.
It seems that the NDP, which is so bankrupt of ideas of its own, when it gets a little desperate, turns not to attacking the Conservatives but to attacking the Liberals. We saw it in the 1988 election campaign when in the last 10 days of the campaign, the Leader of the New Democratic Party spent most of his time attacking John Eimer who had made the free trade agreement the issue of the campaign.
It started its campaign with its leader not even mentioning the issue. Then, he climbed on the bandwagon, and as soon as he was on it, he tried to push John Thrner off the bandwagon. What a bizarre scene that was.
We now see that we are trying to deal with the difficult problems that this, having been put into this relationship, has created for Canadians. What does the NDP do? As the last speaker demonstrated, he spent fully 13 minutes of his 20-minute speech attacking the Liberals, trying to make fun of the idea of renegotiation.
I have a few problems with that. I tried to get an answer from his colleague earlier, unsuccessfully. I look at the weekend edition of The Financial Post from October 26 to October 28 and see on the front page the Leader of the NDP saying or at least being quoted as saying: "If elected, we would sit down with the Americans and say: How can we make this thing work?". It sounds a lot like sitting down and renegotiating to me.
What do we have here? We have the NDP standing up and saying: "No, we are just going to abrogate. We do not mind the fact that this is a huge and complex trading relationship that we have going here. We do not mind the fact that we have countless enterprises in Canada that are reliant upon a trading relationship with the
United States. We will not even try to work out our problems. Day one, we are going to abrogate".
Then, what are we going to do next? One of the things we are going to do, point one of his seven point program, is to look at other areas for deals like the auto pact. I am sure we will make a lot of progress with the United States sitting down and proposing other managed trade arrangements with the Americans, after he has abrogated the free trade agreement on day one without even having begun to discuss the difficulties that we have with it.
The fairy tale that he really should be confronting is the fairy tale notion that the NDP solutions for the Canadian economy in complex times like these can be dealt with by ranting and raving against the Americans.
We do not go up to the biggest kid in the schoolyard and provoke a fight with him. We have to find a way to outsmart him. What we need to do is sit down at the table and work out a relationship with the United States that is going to correct the wrongs of the last few years and find a solution for us to begin to prosper once again.

Mr. Speaker, there are two points that I would make in response to my friend from Ottawa South.

Over the years we have become used to us taking positions based on thinking, based on analysis and based on looking at the world as it really exists.

Sometimes it takes the Liberals, six months, a year, sometimes two years and sometimes it has taken them 20 years as in the case of medicare. Often it has taken a long time for them. Often they have said: "Yes, I guess the NDP was right".
The last point which I would make with respect to this particular comment is simply to say that the auto pact, I should say to my friend, is not with the United States as far as Canada has set it up. The auto pact is something of which any country in the world could be part.

health and safety everywhere. Each year over 1,000 Canadian workers are killed on the job. We must add 11 more in 1992.

Mr. Speaker, the greater Detroit area has 15 airports serving about 4.3 million people. By comparison the greater Toronto area, serving a similar population, has only five airports; Pearson, the Island, Mount Hope, Oshawa, and Button-ville.

In his February budget speech, the Minister of Finance stressed the important contribution that adequate infrastructure like airports make to our competitive position as a nation. He was right. In
1960, one woman out of twenty was likely to have breast cancer. The ratio is now one out of nine, but no one knows why.
