Mr. Speaker, this government prefers to exclude those who do not conform rather than amending the Human Rights Act to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation.
It has condoned the discriminatory practices of the Armed Forces and ignored reports of the independent Security Review Committee which ruled that the military's policy against employing or promoting homosexuals violates the charter.
The latest victim is Lieutenant Michele Douglas, a declared lesbian, who graduated at the top of her class in basic training. As a result of a recent ruling of the Supreme Court of Canada this officer has been denied a top security clearance and lost her job.
We support the recommendation of John Bassett, head of the Security Review Committee, that this government must amend the CSIS act to protect human rights. People of all sexual orientations must be protected under the Canadian Human Rights Act.

Mr. Speaker, tourism was a $26 billion industry in Canada in 1991, employing more than 600,000 people in 60,000 businesses and represents the fourth largest generator of foreign capital into the country.
However, while the world continues to discover the rich diversity this country has to offer, it seems Canadians are increasingly choosing to take their money and travel abroad.

May 11, 1992
Last year Canadians spent $15 billion on tourism outside the country and the federal government has been working to stem this outflow of money by encouraging Canadians to take their next vacation here at home.
As part of this initiative the minister of tourism has launched an extensive advertisement campaign entitled "Canada-A World All Our Own" to remind Canadians that a vacation here is spectacular and good value by any comparison. May 11 to 17 is National Tourism Awareness Week. Let us take a look at where we spend our tourism dollars and see if we can spend a little more here at home.

Mr. Speaker, over this past weekend TransCanada Pipelines unveiled a truly remarkable recycling project located in my riding of Thunder Bay-Nipigon.
TransCanada Pipelines uses turbo compressors to move natural gas. These compressors generated a great deal of heat which was released into the atmosphere. Now the company has developed and built a turbo generator which takes this heat, combines it with additional energy, allowing it to produce 36 megawatts of electric power. In layman's terms, it is enough power for over 20,000 homes.
In essence what it has done is take waste heat, recycle it, and produce electric power. All Canadians should be extremely proud of this Canadian company for its research and development.
Mr. Gerald Maier, president of TransCanada Pipelines and David Russell, vice-president and all of the people involved in this huge project at TransCanada Pipelines should be congratulated on this wonderful and outstanding achievement.

Mr. Speaker, like many Canadians I was deeply concerned when I saw the Toronto riots on TV. We must eliminate racism from our police forces, government agencies and among Canadians themselves.
The mean-spirited Reform Party would abolish the Department of Multiculturalism, end funding for race relations programs, cross-cultural programs, integration and literacy programs. These programs help new Canadians integrate into society. Just when Canadians are looking for solutions to end racism, the Reform Party wants to institutionalize it by ignoring the problems.
The Reform Party naively and ignorantly believes racism does not exist in Canada. It does and we must have the proper machinery in place to deal with it. The Reform Party would make Canada a turbulent, mean, intolerant society.
Canada deserves better than the intolerance of the Reform Party.

Before starting, Mr. Speaker, I am sure that all of us on both sides of the House wish to associate ourselves with the words that were spoken by the member for Cape Breton-East Richmond.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Minister of Finance.
When we talk about economic problems, the minister is inclined to hide behind international projections. I suggest he listen to the local projections from the streets of Montreal: 20 per cent of our young people are officially registered as unemployed, thousands more than a year ago; 36 per cent are drop-outs; and 21 per cent of our families are living below the poverty line.
Yesterday, one of my constituents told me it was the saddest Mother's Day in her life because she was no longer sure her children still had a future.
My question is this: What kind of hope can this government offer a whole generation of young people it ignored during the years that are so decisive for their education?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian economy is weak, and we have acknowledged that, because the world economy is weak. It is not because of our policies. It is a world-wide economic slowdown. That is reflected in the downward revision of the OECD and of the IMF. As the hon. member knows, having been in business himself, Canada's economic activity is based to a large extent upon our ability to export internationally.
I can indicate to the hon. member that with the pick-up in the United States, and the United States is our major trading partner, there is a clear indication of some pick-up on the trade side. Our exports to the United States are improving. That is reflected in some job improvement.
In the case of the statistics that were just reported, some 34,000 new jobs were created in the manufacturing sector; some 24,000 new jobs created in the merchandise trade sector. I should also indicate to the hon. member that we see today a major movement toward greater job training and skills upgrading. I remind the hon. member that 70,000 UI claimants are now engaged in training and skills upgrading. I think that is a very positive indication because that is part and parcel of the restructuring and adjustment process that is going on and the need to upgrade our skills and to retrain our people.

Mr. Speaker, what is truly frightening is that the minister may actually believe what he is saying.
The facts are that the future for our youth is getting bleaker and bleaker with every passing day. Many of our young people cannot get the training which is required for the jobs of tomorrow, and many of those who do have the training cannot find jobs in their field of study. As a result of this government's inaction, we may well be facing an entire lost generation. The question is: How can our young people be expected to compete in the future against European and Japanese youth who are not only being given complete skills and educational training in a wide range of apprenticeship areas, but whose governments have developed the industrial base which is required to develop them?

May 11, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am glad that the hon. member does agree with me because the Labour Market Development Strategy is a clearly designed policy to do just that.
As I indicated, 70,000 UI claimants are now receiving training and that compares to something like 20,000 per month in the first six months of 1991. So really the programs that we have put in place, the replenishment and indeed the expansion of the training fund that I announced in the budget, are a clear indication that we are spending money on skills upgrading and job retraining and that provides encouragement to our young people. It also helps those who are adjusting into a different kind of economy that is emerging. The hon. member knows that and I have heard him speak about it.
The economy of Canada is indeed changing. We have to recognize our educational programs. We have got to recognize our training and our skills upgrading. That is part and parcel of the prosperity agenda that is being so eloquently managed by my colleague, the Minister for International Trade.

Mr. Speaker, this is incredible. The prosperity agenda is simply a lot of useless analysis that is confirming something that everybody in this country has known for a long, long time.
For the love of heaven, get on with the job. The industries of tomorrow are created by the research and development budgets of today, which this government has decimated over its mandate. The exports of tomorrow will be created by the small businesses of today. They require technology diffusion. They require patient capital. Nowhere has this government given any indication that it understands the need.
The question is: When will this government understand the comparative advantage is not something that is simply inherited by a people? It is a stage that is created by farsighted governments.

speechtext:

manufacturing and processing, improving the investment climate, improving research and development, all of which is co-ordinated and synchronized with the initiatives of the Minister for International Trade.

Mr. Speaker, the Minister of Finance says we are on the right track. It is a track that is totally bypassing the province of Manitoba.
In one year alone we have lost 17,000 jobs, 23 per cent of the job losses in Canada since the election took place in Manitoba, even though we have only 4 per cent of the population. Winnipeg has the highest level of child poverty in the country.
I am describing nothing less than the social and economic calamity in which this government totally ignores its responsibility and abdicates any role for investing in the province of Manitoba.
I want to ask the Minister of Finance: In light of these dramatic and tragic figures, will the Government of Canada undertake a special employment and economic development program for the province of Manitoba so our people can go back to work, which is what they want to do?

speechtext:

The hon. member knows that the provincial government brought down what I think was a very prudent budget that was complementary to the initiatives that we undertook in terms of improving the competitive position of the manufacturing and processing sector, improving the climate for small business and improving the climate for investment.

May 11, 1992

prairie region in 1992. That too is a good indicator. That will create economic spin-off. That will create jobs.

the policies of his government have helped to create unemployment. I ask the Deputy Prime Minister what will the government do immediately to at least stop the loss of further jobs.

We certainly are providing and earmarking a lot of funds. What are we going to do in the future? I indicated to the hon. member there is some pick-up in the manufacturing sector. There is some pick-up in the trade sector. What we did in the budget is tiy to identify those weak sectors of the economy, particularly the manufacturing sector, which needs to have a competitive and business environment and which has to have a competitive tax environment, and we have addressed that.
The hon. member suggests that there is an easy answer. I refer her to the recommendation of her employment and manpower critic, the member for Timmins-Chapleau, who said that the government should looking into printing the money it needs to spend its way out of the recession. In St. Catharines, Ontario, as the minister knows, a profitable GM foundry will close, throwing about 2,000 people out of work. In addition to the training needs of this country, we also need some changes in the kinds of agreements we have made with other countries.
Is the Minister for International Trade prepared to ask for increased Canadian and North American content rules for the Canadian auto industry so that we can at least maintain some of the skilled jobs we do have?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:

She knows that we have somewhere around 10 per cent of the population.
With regard to her specific question on content, she is aware this matter is under review in the North American free trade negotiations. There is a range of requests ranging from the current 50 per cent to as high as 75 or 80 per cent.
We are consulting with the industry on a very intensive basis to decide what the appropriate level should be in view of the broad rules of origin, consultations and negotiations that are under way. I will take her comments under advisement as part of those consultations.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
It was this government, in partnership with the Bank of Canada, that embarked on a contractionary monetary policy that was guaranteed to kill jobs and further strangle Canadian workers in the middle of a recession. Rather than protect these workers, this government cut UI benefits and froze welfare payments to the provinces.
I ask the minister to justify his government's deliberate efforts to create unemployment and abandon its jobless victims. When will this government stop blaming unskilled workers for the unemployment it created?

Why is the minister so unmoved by the face of misery on his unemployment figures that he offers only cosmetic remedies to mask the Tory gangrene that has left the Canadian economy with so few jobs? Why have the jobless been erased from the conscience of this government?

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have not been unmoved by the trend toward the higher than acceptable unemployment figures. I want the hon. member and all other Canadians to know that. She can provide simplistic solutions but unfortunately that is not the answer.
What we have to do is get the fundamentals right. We had to ratchet down inflation and bring down the elements that drive up inflation, the inflationary expectations and the inflationary pressures. We had to put in place an appropriate fiscal and monetary policy that was co-ordinated. We have done that and we have had a considerable amount of monetary easing; over seven percentage points since the high of 1990.
These are the fundamentals. We have tried to encourage the housing sector. We have tried to improve the climate for the manufacturing and processing sector, the small business sector, and the investment side of things. These are the kinds of things that are necessary in order to restructure the economy and build a broad based, modem economy that Canadians expect of government.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Deputy Prime Minister.
Last week the Minister of National Health and Welfare made a number of statements which indicate that the government is abandoning its commitment to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000. The minister said: "This goal is an unrealistic dream". For the over one million children living in poverty in Canada, poverty is a real nightmare every day of their lives.
In November 1989 the Deputy Prime Minister voted along with every other member of this House to eliminate child poverty by the year 2000. Have he and the government reneged on this promise? If so, why?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare

poverty is one of the greatest concerns of this government and indeed of everybody in the House.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare

Mr. Speaker, since twelve o'clock today, you as well as I have heard hon. members of the NDP and the Liberal Party state all the reasons why they think Canada should no longer be part of the free trade agreement. But they seem to have conveniently forgotten all of the benefits that have accrued to Canadian businesses as a result of this agreement.
Might I refresh their memory with a few examples? The Clearly Canadian Beverage Corporation is an exceptional Canadian company, based in Vancouver. Clearly Canadian sells natural and flavoured sparkling mineral water. At the beginning of fiscal 1991, the company marketed its products in 30 American states and, by year end, was available in all American states and every Canadian province. Clearly Canadian reported record sales of $71 million in 1991, up 250 per cent from a year earlier.
The company's president, Douglas Mason, attributes part of that success to the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. Let me quote Mr. Mason:
In order to sustain growth in a free trade environment, it is important to be aggressive and active in the market place. There exists a wealth of opportunities and I believe that Free Trade has changed the attitude of business; it has been of great assistance to our company's progress.
3M Canada, based in London, Ontario, is another example of a company that has taken advantage of the opportunities created by the FTA. Just over a year ago, 3M decided to invest $30 million in a new manufacturing plant in Brockville. The company chose Brockville after a year-long search for sites in Canada, the United States and Mexico. It chose Canada because of the tariff reductions offered under the FTA.
Several months later, 3M announced two more investments: the first was to modernize and upgrade its Havelock, Ontario plant, a $5.6-million investment; the second was an addition to the company's plant in Morden, Manitoba, an $ 11.5-million investment.
Do you know why 3M chose to make this significant investment in Canada, Mr. Speaker?
3M's Executive Vice-President, Alfred Cordell, said, and I quote: "Our recent decisions to invest in our Canadian operations reflect our confidence and commitment to our future here in Canada."
Mr. Cordell added: "Long before the free trade agreement was implemented, we were working on rationalization of production, and when the FTA was implemented, we were more than ready to capitalize on it."
Another company, Webcom Limited, prints books, directories and catalogues in Toronto. With the advantages of free trade, the company has refocused its products in the United States and export sales now account for about 20 per cent of total sales. Employment at Webcom also increased by 22 jobs in 1991.
Mr. Warren Wilkins, president of Webcom, says:
The U.S. offers exciting opportunities, and to be competitive, we
must operate as easily in the U.S. as we do in Canada. What the
Free Tirade Agreement does is create a different environment and a
greatly enlarged market. Free Trade has given Webcom access to the
U.S. market, which is a tenfold increase, if not more.
And the list goes on.
Ganong Brothers Limited of St. Stephen, New Brunswick has been making chocolate and confectioneries in Canada for 118 years. In 1990, its export sales grew 180 per cent. In 1991, it was a Canadian Export Award Winner. Company president David A. Ganong said:

Ten years ago, it was clear we were not going to survive or grow if we were only dealing with Canada and Canadian competitors. We had to change our focus. With the introduction of the Free Tirade Agreement, we decided we could make it work here.
Another 1991 Canadian Export Award Winner, Pallis-er Furniture Ltd. of Winnipeg, Manitoba, has made strong gains in the United States.
With 1,700 employees and a value of $161 million, the company challenged the U.S. competition in the moderately priced wood furniture market and it succeeded.
Palliser's president Art DeFehr says:
We told ourselves that when Free Trade became a fact of life, we were going to reposition ourselves so that we could be competitive in a geographical area or product area. Aggressive Canadian companies can compete with the best in the world by focusing their product, their work ethic and their commitment to quality and service.
The Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement has been instrumental in the success of these companies. All have benefited from the elimination of tariffs, special measures to enhance access to American markets, and a more liberalized regulatory framework for investment.
These companies are not front-page news, but they are concrete examples that the FTA is working for Canada.
None of these successes occur on their own. In large measure, they reflect the effectiveness of Canada's market development program in the United States.

All regions actively benefited. Of 4,519 companies directly involved, 25 per cent were from western Canada, 38 per cent from Ontario, 27 per cent from Quebec and 10 per cent from Atlantic Canada.

States (NEBS) initiative. More than 825 firms participated, and experience shows that half of NEBS participants will eventually become exporters.

The Minneapolis show, with a budget of $14,000, resulted in projected sales of $10 million for its 33 participants.

In support of that statement, let me read what some others have been saying about this historic agreement between Canada and the United States.
Peter Morici, writing last year on "A New Special Relationship-Free Trade and U.S.-Canada Economic Relations in the 1990s", said:
The benefits of the FTA reach much further than removing existing barriers and avoiding new barriers to trade and investment. It established processes and a context for better management of the relationship.
Gordon Ritchie in "Free Trade: Year Three" said:
The direct economic impact of the Canada-U.S. free trade agreement, or FTA, has been small but positive, very much as expected, with measurable increases in business investment, trade and output and decreases in prices.

The dispute mechanisms in the agreement place Canada in a better position in the market than any other U.S. partner. This is a privilege not to be despised. It would not only make batteries for Canada, but through its sales and marketing force it would manufacture in Canada and export to parts of Europe.
Since the free trade agreement the U.S. operation has basically given a directive to the Canadian operation that it no longer needs the Canadian manufacturing capability. It can manufacture all the product required for Canada by just adding one or two hours a week on top of the U.S. manufacturing capability. Because of free trade this Canadian branch plant lost its research and development capability. It also lost its manufacturing capability. Now we basically have a distribution centre.
So often this is what is happening with this free trade agreement. That company in Canada is still doing sales.

May 11, 1992

It is going to these trade shows and writing up orders, as the member mentioned during his speech. subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity this afternoon to discuss free trade once again. We are like veterans who always like to talk about past wars and battles, and veterans of the 1988 election will, I think, always be ready to get involved in a debate on free trade with the United States.
I believe that many of the principles we voiced during the election as members of the Liberal Party were justified and still apply today. We saw the problems arising from the free trade agreement as political, not just economic problems. Generally speaking, it was a debate on sovereignty, not merely a matter of trade statistics.

I think that what was important about the free trade debate in 1988 was that we were trying to draw out for Canadians the essential question of whether we were to pursue a policy of independence on the North American continent or we were going to make a crucial decision to allow our policies to become more and more integrated with those of the United States as we moved more fully into a continental policy-making structure.
Therefore throughout the debate in 1988 many of us in the Liberal Party were raising issues that, if we were to categorize them, technically were not trade issues as much as they were issues of political sovereignty, of independence. Much of that position comes from the concepts that led to Canada being an independent nation on the northern half of the North American continent.
Throughout our history we took a different course from the United States. Our historical roots are greatly different. Our economy developed differently because of policies pursued by our national governments. In part this ensured that despite our proximity to the United States, despite the very strong demographic as well as economic links that existed between our two countries,
we always had a foot in some other camp. Throughout much of the early part of our history our ties to Britain and the British Empire, and then the British Commonwealth, gave us that counterweight to continental pressures and enabled us to build an independent policy in many areas, both economic development and foreign policy.
As that important bond to Britain and the Commonwealth has diminished in importance over the years we have felt more and more the tug of continentalism. By the time we got to the 1988 election the continental magnet was so strong as to be almost irresistible.
What we needed from our government then, as we do now, is a counterweight strategy. We need to find a way to once again put at least one of our feet in some other camp other than continentalism. That is not necessarily the best thing for the United States of America.
The United States has clearly indicated what its policy is going to be. It is seeking to build a western hemispheric trade unit in which it will be the dominant force and which will give the U.S. its own counterweight against the emerging trading blocs in Europe and Asia.
The question for Canadians is whether we ought to be fully integrated into that western hemispheric trading bloc or we should pursue an alternative trade strategy that builds more and more on our role as a Pacific nation and our historic links to the emerging democracies of eastern Europe, building on the basis of shared language and culture that we have because of our Ukrainian, Polish, Hungarian, and Czech communities.
We were a safe haven for nationals of many of those countries in their dark years. Now is the time for us to resume the renewal of those relationships.
In essence, that is what was wrong with entering into the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. However, a lot of things have made it go wrong.
Shortly after the agreement was signed and during the election the Advisory Council on Adjustment was doing its work. It published a large volume entitled Adjusting to Win. It highlights the fact that this important free trade agreement was entered into without an adjustment strategy for displaced workers.
May 11, 1992

Shortly after the free trade agreement came into effect the Government of Canada directed, through consultation and discussion, the Bank of Canada to pursue a policy of what is called price stability or zero inflation. The consequences of that policy were that the Canadian dollar increased in value relative to the American currency by about 20 per cent over a very short time. When the trade deal was signed, in October 1987, the Canadian dollar was trading at about 76 cents U.S., and nobody even thought about what the impact of that agreement would be if the dollar reached, as it did last November, 89.5 cents, a major increase in the exchange rate.
Nobody thought about the impact of implementing a free trade agreement concurrently with the implementation of a major new visible sales tax.
We can go to any border community in our country on a weekend and see what free trade has come to mean to thousands and thousands of Canadians who in protesting the GST have brought commercial success to countless U.S. border communities.
In an article published in the G-7 report by Catherine Swift of the Canadian Federation of Independent Business the problems in implementing the free trade agreement and the fiasco that the government has made of this policy are highlighted. She says: "The early period of adjustment for Canadian firms to the trade agreement was effectively scuttled by other policies pursued by the Canadian government. Notable among these other policies were a significant appreciation of the Canadian dollar vis-a-vis its U.S. counterpart, a record high spread between Canadian and U.S. interest rates, further expansion of the total tax burden on Canadians generally and small firms in particular and other policies inconsistent with the FTA such as an absence of action to reduce interprovincial trade barriers leading to the perverse result of higher trade barriers in some instances between Canadian provinces than between Canada and the United States".
This whole strategy, if we can call it that, reminds me of the hockey team owner who goes out and uses his money to recruit a team and thinks he can win without practising and without a strategy to defeat the opposition. We signed the big deal, we got the big player, in the
Supply
government's mind, but we did not have a strategy for winning the big game. In fact, we are now debating, fully three years after the free trade agreement came into effect, the reduction of interprovincial trade barriers. In other words, we went into the major game without even having an intersquad game among ourselves. What kind of strategy is that?
Although I speak as a veteran of the wars on the free trade agreement I am concerned that if we focus too much on this particular agreement we will miss some of the important issues with which we must deal. If we distract ourselves from dealing with the crucial issues of economic policy then we are not going to be able to deal with those things that will affect the well-being of our children in the future. In the past, our economic prosperity has been heavily reliant on the fact that we have been able to exploit our rich natural resources and that we enjoyed a major manufacturing boom following World War II.
Since that time, things have changed quite drastically in the world. There has been the rebuilding of western Europe following World War II and the emergence of Japan as a major industrial force. There has also been the emergence of the new Asian nations. Taiwan, Korea, and Singapore are producing vast quantities of the goods that we consume here in North America. Soon there will be the re-emergence of the eastern European economies which have well educated and skilled workers with very low wage expectations. If they can bring investment and a new infrastructure to bear on their economies they will be able to produce significant amounts of manufactured goods for export.
What does Canada have to do to deal with that? If we spend all of our time focusing on our relationship with the United States, however important that may be, we could well miss the most important challenges that are ahead of us.
In order to meet those challenges there are two things that we should do. First, we should recognize what our strengths are. I for one am sick and tired of hearing the Government of Canada going around telling Canadians that they are not competitive with the rest of the world.
It is time our government stood up and said how good we are, not how bad we are. We continue to have one of

May 11, 1992
Supply
the highest rates of labour productivity in the world. We continue to be highly educated, compassionate people.
We have a strong system of social supports. Our social programs are a strength for us rather than a drain on us. These are things that we have going for us. We have to stop looking upon them as some kind of impediment to our success. What we need to do is recognize our strengths and then recognize the challenges that face us.
The challenges are out there in the new and developing world. We will only face them if we educate our young people, if we provide them with hope, if we provide them with the skills that they will need and if we share with them an understanding that our future economic success and well-being depends on their ability to compete with the rest of the world.
What about the motion today? The NDP has proposed a motion that would oblige the Government of Canada to abrogate the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. As I said in comments earlier today, the speeches I have heard so far are very reminiscent for me of the election campaign, because when the NDP runs out of things to say, it attacks the Liberals.
In the 1988 election campaign, its leader, Ed Broad-bent, forgot to mention the free trade agreement in his opening remarks at the start of the election campaign. Once it became the major issue as a result of the interventions of the leader of the Liberal Party, he tried to get on board. Once he had done that, he tried to push the leader of the Liberal Party off and spent the last 10 days of the campaign in vicious, personal attacks against the leader of the Liberal Party.
Many of us believe that seats were lost due to split votes because of the NDP strategy of attacking Liberals in the 1988 election campaign. Its members come into the House today, having dropped 20 per cent in the polls in the last 14 months. Their leader is on the ropes, they have no policy to offer so they begin ranting and raving about what the Liberal policy is on free trade.
What is their policy? Their policy is simply to walk up to George Bush and punch him in the nose. That is what will do it. Yes, sir, we will tell those Americans that the free trade agreement is history. That is what we will tell them. Then, all those jobs will come back. Those factories, they will all reopen. The investment will pour
into Canada once we have told those Americans where we stand with them.
That is the most naive lot of nonsense that I could imagine. Not only that, I have trouble to believe anything that comes out of that party. I am from Ontario, the home of Bob Rae. Do you remember the agenda for people the NDP brought forward in the midst of the Ontario election campaign? There is not very much of it left. My friend from Broadview-Greenwood points out the hypocrisy of the statements.
There have been two speakers who have been up so far today during this debate. I have been asking them if they have the transcript of the interview that Audrey McLaughlin gave to The Financial Post in which she was quoted as saying: "If elected, we would sit down with the Americans and say, how can we make this thing work?"
That sure sounds like renegotiation, not abrogation necessarily. What are the NDP going to do? If Bob Rae is any example, the NDP will become a lot more pragmatic in government than it is in opposition. This seems to annoy the member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca.
We were in the House on December 10.1 was here at the time and I heard it. His leader, who narrowly defeated him for the leadership of his party, gave a speech. He got up in questions and comments, obviously haunted by Bob Rae in Ontario and preoccupied with taxation.
He wanted to know if the NDP would bring in a minimum corporate tax if elected to power in Ottawa. Here is what he said: "Can she tell us a time frame?" This is the former leader of the NDP and premier of British Columbia asking the present federal leader of the NDP a question. Does she answer it?
"My colleague asks about timetables. Clearly it is the policy of this party to bring in a fair tax system. We have alternatives. Tax reform is a priority."
Is there a timetable? No. She will not even answer questions. I do not think they know what their trade policy is. I think their party is a hoax on trade issues.
The member for Essex-Windsor did not seem to have too many ideas about what renegotiation might mean. Maybe that is their problem.

Where are they?
May 11, 1992

speechtext:
There are none of them in the House. It is their motion but none of them are here. That is not surprising. They do not like to hear the truth.
He does not know what renegotiation means. He seems to have difficulty with the concept. Let me give him some suggestions.
What about subsidies? Articles 1906 and 1907 of the free trade agreement provide for the creation of a working group to discuss subsidies and the definition of subsidies. That has not been completed. That is an item of renegotiation.
What about rules of origin at the core of the Honda Civic dispute between Canada and the U.S. at the present time? Drafters of the agreement agree that the text is ambiguous. That needs to be renegotiated.
What about extension of drawback provisions? These are provided for in the agreement. There is a possible extension. We should be renegotiating those.
What about technical standards and the ability of the United States to impose technical standards as a non-tariff barrier to Canadian goods?
What about agriculture? What about the fact that the Western Grain Transportation Act subsidy is prohibited in exports of wheat to the United States? That should be renegotiated.
What about the export of products containing sugar from Canada to the United States? It is using that to protect its sugar industry. That should be renegotiated.
What about financial institutions? Our financial institutions want reciprocal treatment with the United States, not national treatment. That should be renegotiated.
What about shipping? We have given away transportation on the land. We allow the United States to protect itself with the Jones Act. What about renegotiating that?
Has none of this occurred to the NDP? I do not think so.
We could list dozens of things that could go on the table in the continuing discussions about a complex, multi-multi-billion dollar relationship that exists in trade between Canada and the United States. Surely the only reasonable, prudent course for Canada to take four
years or five years after that agreement has been implemented is to sit down with the Americans, not hostile like the NDP is, not as sycophants like the Conservative are, nose to nose and do business with them to work out the hard parts of our relationship with them.

Mr. Speaker, I must say I am a little baffled by the intervention. I have looked through my notes and I do not believe I used any statistics. I did not refer to disasters. What I referred to in particular was that the implementation of the free trade agreement was done without any consideration for a strategic context in which to implement it successfully.
Looking at it strictly from the point of view of an economic instrument, a macro-economic policy, where I was most critical of the agreement was in the context of its political implications and its effect on Canadian sovereignty. With respect to the economic implications, we can fight back and forth with statistics. Whether the statistics are coming from one side or the other, I suggest to the minister that they are probably not going to get that far with Canadians in the next election.
The issue is going to be: What are we offering the people who are out of work in terms of hope that they are going find a job? If the NDP can convince them that abrogating the free trade agreement will bring some jobs back, maybe they will support that. If the government can convince them that they lost their jobs through no fault of the government, that it was just one of those unfortunate things that came along in the context of international economics and the government was not responsible for it, then maybe they will vote for it. I think we are going to have to present people with a lot more hope and a lot less statistical analysis.
With respect to the trade agreement itself and the macro-economic implications of it, my criticisms-and I did not hear the minister respond to any of these-were as follows. First of all it was brought in without any adjustment strategy despite the fact that when it was being promoted the Prime Minister-and I believe these are the exact words-said that massive adjustment programs would be made available. There were no adjustment programs made available for workers displaced as a result of the free trade agreement.
Second is the impact of the rising dollar on the price in U.S. dollars of our export goods. The minister did not respond to that. I have not alleged any kind of conspiracy on that issue. What is clear is that no attempt was made to manage the exchange rate so that Canadian firms could benefit from the free trade agreement as a result of managed exchange. On the contrary, they were penalized.
Furthermore I said that the GST had an impact on the implementation of the free trade agreement.
There was no comment on any of those. Those were the economic criticisms that I made of the agreement.
As for Catherine Swift, I have no knowledge she is intending to run as a Liberal candidate. I would have to say I would be most delighted if she were to run in the minister's own riding.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Richardson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Transport):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to share my time with the hon. member for Calgary Southwest. She is on a roll today after scoring well in Question Period. However I invite her to join me.
On the question of implementation of benefits to the free trade agreement, I am surprised we are still getting questions and concerns because of the success of the free trade agreement. This agreement, particularly for those of us in Alberta where we have seen immediate benefits from the free trade agreement, has really cushioned
Canada from what would have been an even more severe recession than we have gone through.
Here are some of the facts. Since the FTA came into effect on January 1, 1989, Canadian merchandise exports to the United States have increased approximately 5 per cent. Despite the recession, exports in 1991 matched the average of the first two years of the free trade agreement. The over-all trade relationship totals more than $250 billion.
Net foreign direct investment inflows to Canada between 1986 and 1991 totalled $27 billion or an average of $4.5 billion a year. In comparison, cumulative foreign direct investment flows to Canada between 1980 and 1985, the five years preceding, amounted to a negative $5.4 billion. We can see the obvious benefits of the free trade agreement.
Since the inception of the free trade agreement in 1989 and up until 1991, net foreign direct investment flows to Canada amounted to $5.9 billion, second only to the previous high of $6.6 billion attained in 1990.
In the three years preceding the free trade agreement, 1986 to 1988, cumulative net foreign direct investment flows to Canada totalled $10.4 billion or $3.5 billion per year. The sharp increase in foreign direct investment flow since 1988 strongly reflects upon the foreign investor's confidence in the Canadian economy and the government's structural reforms, the free trade agreement, tax reform, privatization, and deregulation.
Unemployment in the country is too high. This cannot be blamed on the free trade agreement. The fact is that while many of the jobs have been lost in the manufacturing sector, job increases in the service sector are keeping pace.
There have been four regular annual tariff reductions. At the request of industry, two accelerated tariff eliminations have also been implemented since 1989 covering approximately $8 billion in two-way trade with the United States. A third acceleration was initiated in November 1991.
Thirteen more professions made it known that they want to benefit from the temporary entry provisions of the free trade agreement and were approved for facilitation of business travel in 1991.

The dispute settlement provisions of the free trade agreement are working effectively, especially as regards binding binational review of anti-dumping and countervailing actions. A prominent example is the pork case. The binational panel in that case overturned the U.S. determinations and eliminated the countervailing duty on Canadian pork.
No other U.S. trading partner has the same level of protection from U.S. trade actions. No other trading partner has the same right to bilateral review of changes to U.S. trade law.
There is no doubt that the current recession is making it difficult for both governments to manage the bilateral trade agenda. Protectionist pressures are increasing and United States industries are seeking more trade actions against imports.
We have made it clear to the United States administration that we expect them to stand up to these pressures and to meet their obligations under the free trade agreement.
It has been more than three years since the free trade agreement came into force on January 1, 1989. The free trade agreement is the largest trade agreement ever concluded between two countries. Its main goal is to gain improved and secure access to the United States market. The free trade agreement is meeting this goal.
I would like to highlight today the progress that has been made in the implementation of the free trade agreement and the resulting benefits to Canada. I will also speak about developments in the bilateral relationship of which everyone should be aware.
A provision for consultation and revision of free trade agreement rules of origin is included in chapter three. Several amendments of a largely technical nature have been agreed to by a bilateral working group. Changes to the domestic laws of Canada and the United States are being drawn up to reflect these revisions.
The U.S. customs service has ruled that only interest paid on mortgages taken out on real property which is used in the production of goods qualifies for tariff-free treatment under the free trade agreement.
Canada holds the view that certain other interest costs are also eligible under the language of the free trade agreement.
Formal consultations were held in Washington in October 1991. On January 6, 1992, Canada requested a binational panel be established to review the United States decision. The final decision of the panel is scheduled to be released on June 8, 1992.
The valuation of intermediate materials is a key issue in the U.S. customs service audit of the free trade agreement tariff status of vehicles produced in Canada. The audits are a normal part of a customs administrative process carried out by both customs services on a wide range of items. If the conclusions of any U.S. audit are based on interpretations of the free trade agreement with which Canada disagrees, the matter will be vigorously pursued with the United States.
Chapter four of the free trade agreement provides for phased elimination of tariff and tariff-related measures, as well as other restrictive measures applied at the border within the 10-year implementation period of the free trade agreement. Four annual free trade agreement tariff reduction exercises have taken place since January 1989.
The free trade agreement also provides for accelerated tariff elimination at the request of industry. Two rounds have taken place since 1989 eliminating tariffs on some $8 billion in two-way trade in goods. Building on the success of the first two rounds, a third round was initiated in November 1991. Two hundred and eighty requests have been received and are being reviewed. A consolidated list should be published in The Canada Gazette by mid-June.
In order to obtain preferential duty treatment of goods under the free trade agreement, Canadian exporters are required to complete exporter's certificates of origin. Revenue Canada reports that the certification process is working smoothly and that more exporters are incorporating this requirement into their administrative routine.
There is also a free trade agreement provision for refunds on duty paid on free trade agreement tariff-free imports to Canada. In the first half of 1990, Revenue Canada processed over 75,200 requests for free trade agreement duty refunds, of which 85 per cent were decided in favour of the importer.
The free trade agreement obliges Canadian and U.S. accreditation bodies to recognize each other's qualified testing and certification organizations. The Canadian Standards Association has applied for accreditation to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration of the U.S. Department of Labour. The Standards Council of Canada is in the final stages of processing applications
May 11, 1992

for accreditations from Underwriters' Laboratories Incorporated and the American Plywood Association.
The FTA also encourages the development of compatible standards-related measures and procedures for product approval. The Canadian industry associations and standards bodies are developing relationships within their U.S. counterparts.
Examples of co-operation include the agreement between the Electrical and Electronic Equipment Manufacturers of Canada and the U.S. National Electrical Manufacturers Association as well as that between the Canadian Standards Association and the U.S. Underwriters' Laboratories Incorporated.
Agriculture has been a contentious bilateral issue. The free trade agreement calls for a streamlined meat inspection system. Agreement was reached in February, 1990 on a proposal for a new, open-border inspection regime which would allow meat inspected under either country's meat inspection program to move freely between the two countries. The United States failed to implement the agreement and in response on September 9, 1991, Agriculture Canada introduced a replacement system which re-inspects U.S. meat entering Canada at a limited number of designated facilities.
On October 18, one month and nine days later, the U.S. Department of Agriculture published a notice in the federal registrar announcing its withdrawal from the proposals. Efforts are continuing to reach bilateral agreement on an alternative approach to this issue.
The use by the United States of its Export Enhancement Program has resulted in difficulties for Canadian wheat exporters. Under the FTA each country is required to take into account the third country export interests of the other. Nevertheless, the United States has heavily subsidized wheat exports into traditional Canadian markets. Canada has expressed concern that the EEP depresses prices and harms Canadian producers.
Import permit requirements for wheat and wheat products were removed by the Canadian Wheat Board in May 1991 after U.S. subsidy levels were determined to be equal to or less than the level of government support for that grain in Canada.

I just wanted to ask the member why, during the last election, were the doom and gloomers in the opposition saying that all of the plants in my area would be closing down and that my parents, who are senior citizens, were

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Transport
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, one can only speculate as to the motives of the opposition parties when they see the benefits to Canada of the free trade agreement. It is the same kind of scare tactics that the socialists use with regard to medicare today, that everyone is going to lose their medicare. Far from the case. It is simply not going to happen. Nor, as has been suggested by some opposition party members, is it that the free trade agreement would be harmful to Canada.
In fact, the proof is in the pudding. It has been clear to many across the country that we have had a world-wide recession but in fact Canada has been cushioned from that veiy recession through the benefits of the free trade agreement.
The objective of the free trade agreement was to give free access to the American market. Canadians should consider these facts on free trade and the benefits of free trade. We should mention that we are looking at a market here of 26 million people and are now expanding that market to one of 250 million people. This is the benefit to Canadian industry.
Our exports to the United States rose 4.6 per cent in 1990. We sell more to the Americans than we buy from them, $17.4 billion more in 1990 compared to $14 billion more in 1988. So there is an increase just over the two years of the free trade agreement of $3 billion in increased sales to the United States. Since the free trade agreement our exports of aerospace products, engineered industrial machinery, transportation equipment, and chemical products have grown by $4 billion.
Because of the free trade agreement dispute settlement mechanism, which I mentioned in my remarks, our pork producers won a clear victory against their U.S. counterparts. We did not have this alternative before. We did not have this opportunity previously to go after
these anti-dumping and countervail decisions in the United States. We now have an independent tribunal which deals with these and here is a clear victory against United States counterparts and we will be getting back the $20 million paid to U.S. customs.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Barbara Sparrow (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to extend my appreciation to my colleague from Calgary Southeast for sharing his time.
One thing that westerners-I was going to say Albertans, but indeed westerners-realize is that free trade is very, very important for our country to maintain its standard of living and indeed to progress.
Some of our major industries, of course, are agriculture and the petroleum industry and petrochemicals. The free trade agreement which came into implementation on January 1, 1989 has certainly assisted us. It has not all been free and easy and there is certainly no agreement that does not come without a few problems, but we are certainly far better off.
The interesting thing is that Canada, out of all the countries in the western industrialized world, is more trade-dependent than any other country. Actually, about three million jobs depend on trade here, as well as almost 30 per cent of our national revenues. So we in Canada have to trade to maintain our standard of living and indeed obtain the revenues.
But there are critics. I am sorry the hon. member for Ottawa South could not stay in the House because he did pose a question with regard to people forecasting doom and gloom and always suggesting that we Canadians cannot compete. And I just wanted to say to him that-

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext: He said we could.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare

speechtext:
We can. That is absolutely right. But he said there are people out there who are saying that we cannot. We certainly can compete. Obviously, over the last five, six, eight years, this country has been rationalizing its manufacturing business, and indeed its resource industry, whether it is from British Columbia with regard to forestry or Alberta with regard to oil and gas or wheat.
My colleague from Saskatchewan knows very well what high subsidies can do for the exportation of grain, and he knows the major problems we have when we are
May 11, 1992

at the GATT table. Although that is another story, GATT has to resolve those unfair trading practices.
Canadians do not have to be fearful. We really do have the ability to compete. We just have to get out there and sell better, merchandise our products better and build our goods and our services more efficiently. We certainly can do that.
Some people do like to stick their heads in the sand. We have lived very well in this country over the past decades. We are quite dependent on our natural resources in the west, on manufacturing in central Canada, and on natural resources and the fishing industry on the east coast.
The whole world is changing and the globe is changing. It is becoming smaller and smaller. For Canada to negotiate a trade pact with the United States, our closest neighbour, to ensure that we have access to its market is a step in the right direction.
Let us get this straight, there is no such thing as free trade. What we are really discussing is freer trade. Prior to January 1, 1989, 80 per cent of all the goods that we exported to the United States were relatively duty free. We were working on a very small portion and we are pleased to phase out the duties over a period of 10 years. That process should terminate about 1998.
The most important part is the dispute settlement mechanism. When we do have a trade dispute with the United States, and there is just cause and reason, we will be able to take it to a tribunal made up of equal numbers of American and Canadian people with an arbitrator, a negotiator chosen by both sides.
The cause for our dispute would be reviewed and a decision would be made within, I believe is 315 days, less than a year. Prior to this free trade agreement any dispute had to go to GATT. There are 108 countries in GATT and it took six, seven or eight years for the dispute to be resolved. By the time you got through the dispute mechanism arguing your case whether you were right or wrong, the industry was having a pretty tough time.
I would like to ask the critics of the free trade agreement if they have another mechanism that would resolve some of these disputes. We now have an agreement that takes the 240 million or 245 million people in the United States and combines them with our 27 million

and to make a very strong market of 270 million or 280 million.
We have to watch the rest of the world. Multilateral trade is very important. The United States is a major trading partner, but our second biggest trading partner is Japan. Indeed, the Pacific Rim is a very important trading partner for all of us in North America and we look forward to expanding our trade there. Our third largest partner would be the European market.
This year, 1992, is the year that 12 European countries come together in a common market. I believe the number is up to 14. Spain and Portugal have entered the EC so there are 14 countries. There is also talk of the Community expanding further.
While North America is pulling together to improve and set down some relatively strict but flexible criteria for trade we must also realize that Europe '92 represents 350 million or 380 million people. It is a tough market, because it is so large, but we can do it.
I really want to emphasize that this is no absolute magic formula. It has to be worked on by both sides. There is no doubt about it.
We were used to living with protectionism. As we work down these barriers with the United States in the different industries that are involved, agriculture being the last one that we will be working on toward the end of the nineties, it means that goods and services will be able to flow across the border both ways.
The world is now too small for protectionism. Protectionism protects an industry at home, it may give it a tax advantage or a subsidy advantage, and does not really push it to become more competitive.
We can see that Canada stands in an excellent position to improve its trade. As mentioned by my colleague for Calgary Southeast with regard to this dispute mechanism, we did take the pork dispute to it and Canada won. That meant that between $20 million and $24 million was put back into the producers' pockets. The government was also successful in the raspberry dispute a year and a half or two years ago. We do have a problem today with the Honda engine. I can assure the House that if this is not resolved at the border with our people on both sides it must go to the dispute mechanism.

May 11, 1992

It has also helped with the question of softwood lumber. If we did not have this special court to challenge both sides today, we would certainly have a problem.
I look forward to moving through the three to five-year schedules that were set down in the FTA so that we can see more of the goods.
In conclusion, one area I wish to mention concerns unifying the standards between Canada and the United States. This is one area we have to move in. Indeed, we have to move all across Canada in order to get our trade barriers down.
I was very active during the debate in 1989. I certainly support free trade. I support the dispute mechanism that we have used, and it can be improved on. I look forward to the future for Canada. With our resources and our value added, we certainly can improve our trade surplus and our exports.

Mr. Speaker, I was listening very intently to the member's speech and I would like to ask her a couple of specific questions.
Now that we are entering into a new regime of a global economy and a new regime that people classify as a free trade regime, I would be interested in knowing how she feels about the lack of labour adjustment programs in our country to deal with the close to 500,000 Canadians who are out of work. I would like to know whether she feels that is a fair price to pay for a particular change in direction and philosophy from one government to the other.
Whether she wants to use the recession as the reason or not, the fact remains that something in the range of 65 per cent of those jobs lost are due to permanent plant closures. Obviously we must do something with these people to get them back to work. I would be interested to know how she proposes to deal with that because it has become more obvious as we watch the government twist and turn in the wind that this was not part of its strategy when it first entered into the free trade agreement.
Second, I would like to know about the importance, as far as this member is concerned, of an environmental accord with the other countries in this free trade atmosphere that we are entering into. Is it acceptable for a
country like Mexico to pollute the environment and not have any environmental standards whatsoever? That lack of regulations can entice businesses to move to Mexico because it is obviously cheaper to do business when it does not have those regulations.
I would be interested to know what the member really feels about those two very important issues. One is the environmental accords which we do not have and the other is the labour adjustment program for the close to half a million Canadians, 65 per cent of whom do not have a hope in hell of getting their job back once this particular recession everybody is using as an excuse is over. I would like to know whether she can give an answer to those questions.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of National Health and Welfare
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
I thank my colleague for raising a couple of issues with regard to labour adjustment programs. There have been labour adjustments on both sides of the border. If any of us in this House think that only Canadians have experienced job losses over the the past two or three years, it is not true. It certainly has happened in the U.S, England, Germany and Japan.
IBM said that it was laying off some 30,000 workers all around the world, and General Motors is laying off
74,000.
With regard to labour adjustment programs, we could look at the UI program. We have taken some of that funding and put it to job training. That adds up to hundreds of millions of dollars. As well, the Minister of Employment and Immigration announced in the last couple of days a creation program for single parent women to help them get off welfare and be retrained.
As for plant closures, we lived under protectionism for so long in this country that the plants did not upgrade. They did not put in the new technology. We were so far behind we were not competing. I guess, I do not have the statistics in front of me but the hon. member and I can talk about this, that some of those plants probably should have been closed before. For the hon. member to absolutely blame that on the free trade agreement is not fair.
The environment is a major issue. There is a trade agreement coming with Mexico one way or another. We did not initiate it. We are sitting at the table to protect the FTA, the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. Mexico does have some very good environmental stan-
May 11, 1992

dards but it does not implement them, nor does it have an environmental act.
The way to assist our colleagues is by being there. When we work with Mexico and trade with it we would have far more strength in an advisory capacity. We could even force it to meet North American standards on the environment.
One thing that is interesting is that by the year 2010 Mexico's population will be larger than the United States. It is getting huge. It will be a trading partner. I would like to sit down and make sure that there are some rules and guidelines to not only protect labour adjustment programs but also our environment.

speakeroldname: Mr. Francis G. LeBlanc (Cape Breton Highlands-Canso):
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-CANADA-U.S. FREE TRADE AGREEMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I rise today to add my voice, and that of my constituents, to the important debate that is currently before the House concerning the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement and the motion by the NDP.
First, I would like to express my deepest sympathy to the families of the coal miners in Plymouth, Nova Scotia whose lives were beset with tragedy early Saturday morning. My thoughts and prayers are also with the 26 souls who were working in the mine when the explosion occurred.
Nova Scotia has a long history of coal mining, and its history of disasters of this nature is just as long. My native Cape Breton has endured this kind of agony before and so our hearts go out to the families and the communities of those affected. We can but hope that some good will come out of this terrible event and that the memory of those fallen miners will ultimately serve a greater purpose.
With this in mind, I would like to turn my attention once more to the debate before this House concerning the NDP's stated intent of abrogating the Canada-U.S. Free Trade Agreement. I am sure that some people will criticize the motion of the member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca. They will see this motion as yet another example of his party's wont to embrace simplistic and expedient political postures as a means of scoring cheap political points.
I will not comment on this except to say that I do not believe the motion before the House to be irrelevant even though I fundamentally disagree with its premise at this time. This debate has enormous bearing on the
Supply
shape of Canada's trading relationships, not only with the United States but with the world.
Not unexpectedly we have heard differing accounts of what the impact of free trade with the United States has been on Canada. On one side of the debate we are told that virtually every job lost and every social ill has been a direct result of the free trade agreement. On the other side it is argued that free trade has been good for Canada and that its benefits have merely been offset by the impact of the recession.
Once again, Canadians find themselves being asked to choose between diametrically opposed positions. They are expected to sift through a plethora of facts and opinions and reports and surveys which have arisen since the free trade agreement came into effect. They are being asked to decide who is most accurately reflecting the reality of the economic impact of free trade and what it means for the future.
This was the choice which befell Canadians in the 1988 federal election, a choice which became increasingly difficult as campaign rhetoric reached a fevered pitch. The issues at hand were of immense importance, as they are today, and as such should be measured against what are in Canada's best interests. As in 1988, this must be our guiding principle today.
As such, the first thing we must collectively realize is that Canada is a trading nation. This is something which my friends to the left seem to have forgotten. So much of what we hold dear, our standard of living, our social programs, our very way of life depends directly on our trading relationships with other nations.
Trade is the lifeblood of Canada's economy. Over 40 per cent of our Gross National Product is as a result of our trade. One in every three jobs in Canada relies on trade. Over the last few years this reliance has come to have an even greater significance as the global economy undergoes rampant change. Money in its movements no longer recognizes international borders. Instead it recognizes productivity and efficiency and above all else competitiveness.
The member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca and his party would have us believe that the abrogation of the free trade agreement with the United States would be some sort of panacea for our economic problems. Members of the NDP would have us return to the days of protectionism and high tariff walls regardless of global economic reality.

May 11, 1992
Supply
As economic strategies go, this would be disastrous, at least without overwhelming evidence to the contrary. But the NDP are far less concerned with Canada's economic strategy, it would seem, than they are with their own political advancement. They see the Conservatives, on the other hand, defending the free trade agreement and trying to downplay the economic ruin which has been brought about by the recession and by their own economic mismanagement.
On the other hand, the NDP think the Liberal Party's position, calling for a renegotiation, can be exploited. The Liberals would keep free trade with the Americans, they say. No different from the Tories, they say.
The member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca went as far as to suggest this morning that renegotiation would be a cop-out. His colleague the member for Essex-Windsor called renegotiation a fairy tale. Only the NDP will do the right thing and abrogate the free trade agreement, they say. A vote for the NDP is a guarantee to Canadians that there will be no need for difficult decisions, they would have Canadians believe. Everything will be fine. I mean, has it not worked that way in Ontario?
No, Mr. Speaker, it has not worked that way in Ontario. It has been just the opposite for Bob Rae and his cohorts. Their adversarial posturing in opposition has given way to the crashing economic realities which face not only Canadians, but nations around the world.
Bob Rae can no longer afford to take positions that merely sound good, positions that exploit fear and economic hardship. Bob Rae's government has learned the hard way and Ontarians are paying the price of their education.
Would that Mr. Rae's NDP cohorts here in Ottawa might have learned the same lesson: that political expedience carries a heavy price. That is why it scared me when I heard the member for Esquimalt-Juan de Fuca say this morning that his party is alone in principle in calling for the abrogation of this deal.
This having been said, I nonetheless believe that the debate before the House is an important one. I know that Canadians have suffered tremendously as a result of the recession and that many of the flaws of the FTA have caused great problems for our economy. There is no denying that the free trade agreement, as negotiated by
this government prior to the last election, is fraught with flaws. These are made all the more untenable when one considers that the government was warned repeatedly about the perils of signing a deal without adequate safeguards and definitions.
When the Prime Minister blames our trade woes on low level harassment from the United States administration, he should instead blame himself and his government for not going the extra mile during the negotiations, and for ignoring the implications of signing a deal that was ill-defined in some parts and incomplete in others. Such was their desperation in wanting to get a deal.
Much of what has befallen Canada since the implementation of this deal can be directly attributed to this government's failure in this regard and to its failure to obtain the guarantees and safeguards that would have protected Canadian interests from punitive American trade actions.
Where are the safeguards which might have prevented the dumping of American products in Canadian markets? Where are the safeguards on rules of origin and content? Where is the much talked about definition of subsidies? If the Minister for International Trade is to be believed, it is to be found in the Dunkel text of the current GATT negotiations.
Of course, if GATT negotiations grind to a halt then what does the Minister for International Trade propose? Perhaps he could tell us that.
Free trade with the United States has taught Canada an important lesson, namely that the Americans are only too ready to exploit the omissions and the flaws contained in this deal if it is in their own interests.
There were no tears shed south of the border for our workers in the Canadian beer and lumber industry, in the furniture industry, in the mining industry, in agriculture or in manufacturing. This government has learned too late that however cosy the relationship between the Prime Minister and the President, the Americans are in no mood to pussyfoot around when it comes to trade.
They are not going to let the perception of a special relationship get in the way of their bottom line. If there is a buck to be made at the expense of Canadian jobs, then so be it. If there is a vote to be had by American

politicians at the expense of Canadian interests, so much the better.
It is no coincidence that Canada's top two trade negotiators during the negotiations, Gordon Ritchie and Simon Reisman, are now on record as stating that U.S. trade remedies have greatly weakened Canada's position in terms of its agreement with the United States.
Gordon Ritchie said only last January: "One of the basic assumptions I made was that the Americans, having signed the deal, would not behave in an aggressive and unwarranted way toward its largest trading partner".
Simon Reisman, who was Canada's chief negotiator said: "The Americans are behaving like real thugs these days in protecting their interests".
The reality is that these gentlemen would not be making statements like these if the government had heeded our warnings. It should have realized that with a new global economy emerging, which is both lean and mean, we cannot take anything for granted, especially when it is Canada's economic and social well-being that are at stake.
In the last federal election, the Liberal Party opposed this free trade deal with the United States. It is important to note, however, that we opposed it on the basis of how it had been negotiated and on the basis of its flaws which have since become glaringly obvious.
We in the Liberal Party are nonetheless in favour of increased trade as a means of protecting and enhancing the standard of living which Canadians enjoy. We made this clear in 1988 and our belief in this position dates back nearly a century.
This is a marked difference from those in the NDP who feel that our standard of living in Canada is somehow a birthright. Ideology, it would seem, does not permit the NDP to take a hard look at the facts, except of course when they are forced to do so, as is now the case in Ontario.
This is a lesson which the governing Conservatives should also take to heart. The main preoccupation of this government in dealing with its economic woes seems to be finding someone to blame. Its inability to control the deficit, even after years of continuous growth, is blamed on previous governments or on the provinces.
Supply
Punitive American trade action is blamed on low level harassment and not on its own failure to negotiate appropriate safeguards. Likewise, it is far too easy to blame every job lost on the free trade agreement, although it is clear that the impact of free trade with the United States is one of the reasons why over 1.5 million Canadians find themselves unemployed.
There have been devastating job losses in Canada's manufacturing sector which the government cannot simply dismiss. How much of this job loss can be attributed directly to free trade or to high interest rates, or to a high dollar? Who can say?
At the same time the Minister for International Trade talks about twisted figures and distorted trade. Surely he is not immune to the misery his government has created through its economic policies. Surely he is not looking to blame others for his own government's economic mismanagement.
I wonder if the minister would have the nerve to stand in his place today and to claim that we enjoy secure access to American markets. Was that not what obtaining a free trade agreement with the United States was all about? We certainly used to hear the words secure access a great deal from this government. How times change.
The same can be said of the government's failure with regard to preparing Canadians for the implementation of the free trade agreement. Any initiative which this government has taken since January 1, 1989, has been after the fact and in many cases far too late.
