It is easy for many people to consider themselves free traders when times are good, when the economy is growing and when exports are rising. It is not so easy when times are tough. It seems to many wellnigh impossible when our best and most important trading partner seems to be responding to political partisan protectionist pressures.
As a result many are saying that we as a government and as a country were naive when we entered into the free trade agreement. Some may say we were misguided. Some may say we were uncaring. Others will suggest it is time to let it go. None of the above are true. None of the above suggestions that we would let go are responsible and could work.
Instead, when times are tough it is time more than ever before for us to be constant in our trading arrangement. We of all the trading nations in the world depend on trade. Per capita, Canadians depend on trade three times as much as the United States. We depend on trade twice as much per capita as the people of Japan. We consider Japan and the United States to be examples of some of the greatest trading nations in the world. Canadians depend upon this foreign trade more than either of those nations.
For those I have heard from British Columbia who suggested that the free trade agreement was not good, it fills me with horror and I am mystified by it. In the discussions just a week ago with industry leaders from the cattlemen's association, from the mining association and from the forest industry, the one single message they had for our Prime Minister was: "Stay firm on our free trade agreement. We depend on that free trade more than any other province in Canada".
Are we being indifferent to the plight of Canadian auto workers, lumberjacks, miners and brewers in holding the course? Not in the least. We have and will continue to deploy every resource and opportunity to defend our interest and help those in need. We will do so with all the vigour and all the tools at our disposal, but we will do it within the rules.
There are those in the United States and in Canada who may be prepared to risk a return to the jungle. I am not one of them. Nor is this government. There are those who offer counsel of despair. There are those who say that Canadians cannot compete with the rest of the world. There are those who want to abrogate the
agreement. There are those who want to retaliate emotionally, to hit back. That is easy to say but difficult to do effectively. Experience has shown that few retaliatory actions ever hit the target. More often than not it means shooting yourself in the foot.
While we will not fall prey to any short-sighted and self-defeating approach, we do not need to adopt a siege mentality either. The rules of the free trade agreement bite both ways. Where we think the Americans are wrong, we will use the rules to defend our interests and we should use those rules then. We will not be shy. Using the rules may not always give us quick relief but it leads to lasting relief. It is a relief based on the sound foundation of rules rather than the momentary but deceiving rush of retaliation.
The economic circumstances which disposed us to take the road to free trade at the beginning of our mandate have, if anything, become more compelling. In 1985 we were only seeing early signs of the phenomenon since dubbed globalization. Today the signs are unmistakable. We, like the Americans, the Japanese and other great trading nations are increasingly part of that global economy. This world poses direct challenges to Canada which can be summed up in a simple phrase. By the end of the decade we must transform ourselves from a trading nation into a nation of traders.
The free trade agreement, the GATT negotiations, trilateral negotiations with Mexico and the United States, our prosperity initiative, the February budget and learning initiatives-all of these programs are based on the premise that we must transform Canada from a trading nation into a nation of traders.
No one doubts that we are currently a trading nation. Over the past decade we have exported about a quarter of our production every year, most of it to the United States but a lot of it to markets all over the world. We can compete and we do compete. However it is sad to say that we are not yet a nation of traders. Our trading culture still remains too shallow. We still export too limited a range of products to too few markets. Not enough companies have an export vocation. Not enough Canadians accept that international business is the key to future growth. Not enough Canadians accept that we have to be competitive on a world scale, that every Canadian must have a stake in the global economy. We will not achieve that by hiding from the world. We will
May 11, 1992

not achieve that with one-way free trade. We will not achieve it if we do not adapt.
Trade is where the domestic economy meets the international economy. A successful export performance is a pretty good indication that the domestic economy is working, that it is competitive. It is an indication that our economy is adjusting and becoming more productive.
Our past record speaks well, but we have to still do better. We have to improve our productivity. We have to keep prices stable. We have to accept competition at home as well as abroad. We have to invest in the future and provide an attractive investment climate for both Canadian and foreign investors alike.
That is why the Canadian government negotiated the free trade agreement with the United States. That is why we are negotiating a trading agreement between Mexico, the United States and Canada. That is why we want to reduce the debt. That is why we want to keep inflation low. That is why we want to reduce the heavy hand of government in the economy. The result will be a growing, stronger, outward looking economy that provides not only a future for us but, more important, for our children.
In 1988, just prior to the free trade agreement, there was a net direct investment outflow from Canada of $2.5 billion. In 1990 Canada enjoyed a record net direct investment inflow of $4.3 billion. The difference since the free trade agreement is over $6.5 billion in our favour. We also maintained a healthy trade surplus with the United States and it has grown since the free trade agreement. Our exports have continued to grow. Some of that export growth has been manufactured goods, such as electrical machinery, rolling stock and high-tech products such as aerospace equipment and scientific and professional instruments.
Obviously we are a nation of resources. Many of our exports are in the resource area. Unfortunately, plant closures and job losses get more press than new investments and increased exports. The success stories of free trade are real. There will be more of them as our economy recovers from the recession and they will provide the base for strong, adaptable industrial sectors.

Instead of allowing manufacturing corporations to simply shut down plants and relocate their operations to another country to take advantage of cheap labour conditions, we need to ensure that Canada implements domestic content rules.
That would make sure that if a corporation is trading in Canada, is wishing to sell its products in Canada, then it should have some commitment to jobs and investment in Canada. That corporation should give something back to Canada rather than just sell goods from the cheapest possible supplier.
The auto pact is a good example of this managed trade where corporations have taken a responsibility selling products in Canada and ensuring that they produce products in Canada too.

This would support family farms and maintain effective food safety standards.
Orderly marketing systems and supply management which are under threat now from pressure by the United States and the GATT should be strengthened. They should be established in areas where they do not exist to ensure that farmers have a fair return for the cost of production and to ensure that consumers have stable food supply.

That this House condemn the Minister of Employment and Immigration for his continual failures to provide the House and the people with accurate and unambiguous factual information on this matter.
